I was a seller for few months. Not a single complaint from a client etc. Everyone was happy. Then suddenly account gets blocked without explanation. First I thought it's a technical error.  I called up the customer rep and was told that someone will call be back within 2 days. No one ever called. I repeated the above about 5 times. No one ever got back to me. I thought that my account got hacked and sent a letter directly to Amazon UK. Just like with the phone calls, they didn't bother to respond. It became obvious that the company has something to hide. I have a reason to believe that I was a victim of discrimination and they don't want to admit that so I can't sue them.  I spoke to a lawyer about the whole thing and I requested copy of my documents via letter. They refused to provide me with information whom should I address in that letter (so called data controller) which is already an offence in the EU. I got it somehow and sent a letter but just like before they ignored it (offence number two: they're legally obliged to respond within 40 days) I had to use legal letter to get ANY response. Their response was that they wouldn't give me anything until I verify my ID. So I did. Now they request a copy of my lease :D I believe I'm on something here. A company that doesn't have anything to hide doesn't act like that so I will continue my journey. Also as a way of saying thank you for their cooperation I will be creating a special website and facebook page which guides people on how to get their information from them step by step, for free.

Absolutely horrible company with a really shaddy record when it comes to dealing fairly. They claimed they were advertising "natural turquoise" and when you go to their page all it has was Chinese imported junk!!!! Disgusting that they can get away with things like this.

In addition to part-timers having to work 11 hours on their feet, they must also rush and race because they are being timed as they pick orders. They only receive a 30 minute lunch. By the time one gets to the time clock which is located on the opposite end of the warehouse, and/or utilize the restroom one has 20 minutes left of lunch. Associates are running around having to beat their time instead of focusing on getting the job done in a safe manner. The store only had 2 days without injury which speaks for itself. On my first day, an associate was bleeding from his cheek. Injuries range from knee, arm, head, foot, etc. Working conditions are not what they are suppose to be like for human beings. Vending machines are broken in order to get proper PPE (e.g. gloves, glove liners). I am canceling my Amazon Prime membership and never buying from Amazon again. Working conditions are disgusting. Being fast should not be what is important, SAFETY is what is important. Amazon would not be the world's most "customer-centric company" without its associates. One can't even utilize the restroom unless they are on break or lunch, because it affects their time, and management will take note of it, so additionally employees must also train their bladder. Sad. To the CEO Mr. Bezos: Instead of having employees yell "CORNER" and "CROSSING" when moving along the aisles, you would benefit from not timing employees like they are animals fetching, and concentrate on a humane work environment that is safe for all. Thank you.

We are a registered company (HDT Europe) with registered products (Herbal D-Tox). We are trying to make our products available for sale in Amazon.co.uk platform since June 2016, with no success. Yes, since June last year! Since then, we are continuously finding obstacles in the form of several documents that are being asked by the Verification Team, over and over again. Every time we submit a perfectly valid document they ask for another one, sometimes they even had that document, but did not considered it at first! Then, they take their time to verify and tell us sometime later than our first document is outdated or has any other "problem". They do not communicate well within their organization because everytime we talk to one of their associates to get help (countless times, by now) they tell us different things. They ask us to submit blank documents! They ask us to send them documents using fax, instead of email! They only verify our documents better when we get really upset and respond harshly to their nonsense email requests! Are we being discriminated here for some reason? Because we know several companies that work with Amazon.co.uk and did not find this endless loop of problems! Why can't we just start selling after all this time?! We are not planning to wait another eight months. Why aren't their associates doing their job correctly?! This is beyond unacceptable, and by our experience we would never recommend Amazon.co.uk as Sellers! Best regards, HDT Europe

This is the first time I've ever had a complaint about Amazon.  The #AmazonPrime payment process is ridiculous and borderline unethical. I went in to pay through the student page so that I can see the student price. It didn't come up when I hit "continue," nor was there a button or drop arrow to get the student discount. There was no breakdown of payment or "confirm payment" button, as there usually is, so I hit continue and was informed that I was signed up for #Amazon Prime. THEN I got a notification from my credit card company that $105 had been charged to my account. THIS IS RIDICULOUS. WHEN YOU SAY "THE FIRST HOWEVER-MANY-MONTHS IS FREE," THAT MEANS YOU DO NOT PAY UNTIL THAT FREE PERIOD IS OVER. THAT IS HOW IT WORKS WITH EVERY PAYMENT PROGRAM. Additionally, nowhere does it SAY that we will be charged immediately.

I madde a purchase from Amazon on 12/14. now i have been purchasing from Amazon for years and never had a problem. I was not aware at the time of the purchase that this item was coming from an individual. My order gets updated on 12/15 with a bogus tracking number and the status has not changed since 12/15. I contact Amazon and all I get is you will have to contact the seller and wait 1-2 weeks for a refund. I have contacted the seller several times and there is no phone number and you can only email them. Amazon still will not take responsibility for scammers on their site. When my account was debited it shows Amazon. But they are saying that they gave the money to the seller and will not refund me because the item has been shipped. Even though they can see that the tracking number is not valid on the USPS site. They have no records of the tracking number. The has been the worst experience ever. And all they keep saying is that we cant refund you and this is the only order that you have placed. I guess because they are under the assumption that I have only placed one order they dont care. We have over 10 accounts with them because everyone in my house has their own account. So with that being said I guess because this account only shows 1 Im not important to them. And yes all of my accounts have prime membership and on top of that its not the free trial. Its a paid subscription. They have people who get on the phones and claim to be managers of the company and when you call back for them no one knows who they are. I also think that thats unfair to lie to your customers to get them off the phone. I have given them nothing but good reviews in the past but after this I will never think to use them again. Everyone be very careful of what you purchase on this site. Because its not up to Amazon to give you a refund its up to the seller. So if your item ships and you never get it you will wait forever for a refund and to think this was a Christmas Gift. And yes my money is very precious to me when I work for it everyday. ORDER # 109-4854477-2456263 1:57 AM	Package has left seller facility and is in transit to carrier Carrier: USPS, Tracking #: EV778522419CN This is all thats available with the tracking number and this is on amazon site.

When I asked how could this be when I was selling USED CANON CAMERA!? there where no answer. then after 2 weeks I received letter that amazon decide to close my seller account. Ok. But I ask them to withdraw my balance to my bank account. They told me - that it going to happen automatically. 3 month later - nothing. No money no connection with amazon - because my account is already closed so I can't enter it and withdraw my money by my self. All I hear from amazon: if you have a problem contact us directly from your account. When I explain my problem they advice my to login and contact them directly from my seller account. So amazon.com for me is just another global fraudsters with huge money which they've stolen from persons like me. without any explanations. I understand that maybe there where reason for closing my seller account but my money which was hold for stuff I sold are still mine! And I am not Santa, at least not for amazon!

Has anyone tried to self publish an e-book with Amazon Kindle. If you have then you will likely agree with me. Writing any kind of book takes 100's of hours. Then there's your cover and so on. I found this company to be an absolute nightmare every time I published a book. Your formatting will always be wrong and your book will look terrible even if you use their own software. They will accuse you of copyright infringement and reject your book over and over. Sure I sold a few books, but I don't think it was worth the aggravation. I would advise you to look elsewhere. The last straw for me came when they started rejecting images. Not content but images from an online source that offers freely available content. And by the way, their mobi file format is ancient history.

I bought a Grundig Satellit 750 Radio from Amazon, when it arrived in Bago City Philippines the shorwave did not work.  I had been warned that Amazon will often ship defective items to people who will have difficulties returning these!  I could not afford the $100 out of pocket after spending so much for this radio (plus customs and shipping) $558.59. Amazon did not offer to reimburse me for the total costs to ship the item back to them DESPITE THE FACT THAT THE ITEM WAS DEFECTIVE (offering only up to $20.00 of it). So since the AM/FM works I decided to keep this DEFECTIVE RADIO! Well due to the fact that our voltage is 220V here, I ordered a power cord for this radio from Super Power Supply and according to Amazon it was shipped via DHL but when I contacted DHL they said it was shipped via Global Mail ( REGULAR MAIL) but I paid $18.00 for this item to be shipped here via DHL EXPRESS! I then went online to write a scathing review of this product and received this"Your review could not be posted." According to Amazon's TOS... This is the copy of that review. "Buyer Beware SCAM ALERT! I live in the Philippines and paid Amazon to ship this to my home address. According to Amazon it was shipped by DHL. According to DHL this item went Global Mail! I have not received the package. I can not ask for a refund due to the fact that I can't send back a package that I have not received! I have asked them to send another one but I doubt that this company will. I paid $18.00 with shipping and customs! This was not CHEAP SHIPPING! Yet this company decided to ship it via regular Philippines Post and lie and say that DHL shipped it! Do not trust this company! I have not received the item. I have waited a very long time to write this. I wrote a review earlier (thinking it was with DHL due to Amazon but this review is about the fact that it WAS NOT SENT VIA DHL) I guess we can't trust AMAZON either! Since their site says it was shipped via DHL!  We encourage you to revise your review and submit it again. A few common issues to keep in mind:  Your review should focus on specific features of the product and your experience with it. Feedback on the seller or your shipment experience should be provided at www.amazon.com/feedback. We do not allow profane or obscene content. This applies to adult products too. Advertisements, promotional material or repeated posts that make the same point excessively are considered spam. Please do not include URLs external to Amazon or personally identifiable content in your review." This review you will notice does not have any foul language in it, other than mentioning Amazon several times and my expectation that when they say they shipped something via DHL that it actually is shipped via DHL and not REGULAR MAIL!. You can not trust Amazon. They will send you broken items that cost you hundreds of dollars due to the fact that you would not wish to trust them, or pay the very high return shipping costs! But also they say that they ship a item via a carrier and it turns out to be a LIE! Do not trust these two companies!   There are very few companies that allow one the selection Amazon does and for me and others who are living in a foreign country (I'm from the USA) a company like this is very useful. But when they send a radio as they did me, that is DEFECTIVE and which I paid such a large sum for, and then only offer $20 to return it...well enough said(?) Do not trust Amazon with expensive purchases. Do not trust the company I bought the cord from, as it was not the correct cord and was not shipped by DHL but by regular mails which has a history of theft here! Ok? So that is all I have to say about this.

So, my Kindle Voyager died that I purchased in Feb. 2015. I jump on chat, they take me through the paces, and decide it can't be fixed. What do you mean it can't be fixed? It's just a dead battery. Oh, we can't fix hardware problems. Okay, well, I'm not paying $199 retail for a brand new one, so, what can you do? Answer: $20 off a new one. NOPE! I call, speak with a guy named Arthur. I explain everything, and he says not to worry; which immediately made me suspicious. I tell him I need to purchase it on a payment plan after he tells me he's selling me the new device for $100. He says he'll give me $40 credit to be used as the first payment, and put $59.99 in my account to be used to make subsequent payments. I made him explain this 3 times. He kept saying not to worry, and he'd send me an email with all the details and his name ... just purchase the device, and he'll do all these things on his end. So, I do it and wait for the email. I get the email, and it says $159.99 for the device with payments to begin the first month and his name is missing. Now, all the messed up crap begins. I decide they lie over the phone, so I start a chat. The woman is a moron and can't understand what I said happened during the transaction on the previous day. We go around and around, and then she then says she found $59.99 sitting in promotional credits and can't be applied to payments. WHAT? What does that mean? It means the $59.99 can only be used for future purchases. I tell her that's not right, and someone needs to fix this. She passes me onto someone else who says he will refund $59.99 to my card. Hours have past, and it's like 1am. I'm so tired at this point, I'm almost falling asleep. I tell him to do so, and I'll check back the next day. I check my account & emails the next day, and nothing happened. I'm saving some of these chats since amazon.com conveniently doesn't allow you to save them. I call to speak with a supervisor, and I'm already tired and frustrated. I get passed around, put on hold for 45 minutes, and hang up. I call back and get hung up on at least 5 times. Now, I'm steaming mad. I'm back to chats since people are jerking me around over the phone. I tell them someone needs to fix this, redo the payment schedule so that the device is $100 like Arthur promised me it would be. I get passed around some more. I ask to speak with a supervisor, and I'm absolutely sure I wasn't speaking with a supervisor who blew me off. Every month, I'm chatting with people, pasting previous chats in the window from Word documents, and asking them what they plan to do. I get the device, and one of them tells me to send it back and they'll redo everything for $100. I ask him if he thinks I'm stupid, because everybody is saying something different and now I don't trust any of them. Send me an email saying this is what would happen if I send it back. He says no, which makes me know he's lying too. In September, I file a BBB complaint. Whoever answered refunds $41 because they took so long, I bought some mp3's which reduced the credit, and before I could ask about redoing the payment schedule, the BBB closes the case. So, I enter another BBB complaint about that. Nothing happens. I get into another chat whereby that rep says he will have someone from the BBB division of Amazon.com address the complaint. Nothing happens again after a couple of weeks. So, then I enter in a complaint with the Attorney General of the State of Washington ... Seattle. Someone at Amazon.com sends back a double-talking response without addressing the payment plan ... again. The Attorney General's office says there's nothing they can do and to go to small claims court for resolution. I send back an email with ALL the chats attached and tell them I've been deceived, and small claims court where? Washington? I don't think so! These people act like this isn't an online company and the laws of one State can govern the laws of another. So, now Amazon.com decides to deactivate my device on 10/7/16 so it can't get any books online. Fine with me! It's their money they're losing out on, not mine. And for what? Just so they can do and say whatever they want to and not do right by me? I'm in dire straights, and they keep sending emails saying they want to take $80 from my card, instead of $40 twice and one payment of $20. I've spent thousands of dollars with Amazon.com on various products over at least 10 years, and they dare treat people like this and make me out to be a liar about the whole thing? I tell them if they were paying me by the hour, with all the hours, days, months I've spent trying to get them to do the right thing, the device would be paid for by now. My time is money too! Nobody is a consumer advocate for online businesses, and a company as large as Amazon.com thinks it can do whatever they want. I think I've also written the FTC ... not sure ... but, they're another useless organization who does nothing about anything. Companies are running rip-shod over consumers, and are being held accountable for NOTHING! They're a monopoly, and there's almost no way around purchasing things online without going through Amazon.com. I'm disgusted and definitely looking for other options to help with this. Any ideas, folks?

I am an indie author. I have dealt with Amazon for over a year and half. Mostly a good experience. But when my add is rejected for a few words that implied affection and desire by my two main characters. I thought you have to be kidding! I did my research prior to submitting my new campaign. And checked out what other author's add text said....far worse than mine! However these particular authors were making Amazon alot of money. I'm Not! Double standards! Unprofessional! I contacted the review team via the support comment box and I was told each campaign text is reviewed on a case by case basis. And my add was declined for its implied sexual content. I must add Support was very quick to respond to my concerns when I told them I was closing my account and I wanted my credit cards deleted. Otherwise there is no support!

Ordered a birthday present from them a year and a half ago. Arrived on time, no complaints there.  BUT....  They apparently now follow me around everywhere I go, whether I want it or not. Have never downloaded an app, I block cookies, but they do it anyway... Earlier this year I wanted to research a small subculture in India, when suddenly a popup appeared from Amazon telling me they could sell me both a book and DVD about the group. I called, complained. They adamantly refused to tell me how to get rid of Amazon's installation, told me to call Apple. Once in a while, I accidentally touch something on the tablet's keyboard and a long, vertical popup appears in lavender print, entirely in alphas aand numerics except for one word at the top: Amazon. So firstly there is this violation of privacy and secondly, why would I pay more plus shipping for the same thing I can get from a brick and mortar mom and pop locally? I would never buy enough to want Prime, and they lost my patronage when I found out they spy on all my online activities. It was creepy. They charged more for that present than the local store, and charged more for shipping than if I did it myself. I can't even go there to see what merchants sell, and then go directly to that merchant, because Amazon tracks me everywhere, apparently. It was their stubborn refusal to tell me how to eject them from my tablet that concerns me. By the way... I just phoned Amazon to tell them that I am starting to warn people online about their invasion of privacy, and the first person that answered is a Filipino... I demanded to speak to an American that I could understand without a Creole accent. I think Amazon should be hiring Americans, there are plenty of jobless Americans who have families to support, but Amazon is on the cheap and doesn't care about their own country.

It's now 8/15 and the kid still did not received the wheelchair for his school. This is his first day in a brand new school. He was so disappointed. I'm not a huge Amazon shopper because their prices are generally higher than my other options but I always check. I do have Prime and love using their music app. I also like the movie and tv show apps and I even have a Fire Stick which is side loaded. Customer service about order issues is great.  As for shipping, I'm literate enough to understand that if something may not be in stock or that it may not be sorted into the warehouse yet and that there may be a delay and shipping times start when the packages ship. If I am not a Prime member then I won't receive as fast of shipping because I can't get faster shipping than those who pay for the faster shipping option. That would make no sense! I know that a package isn't late until the expected delivery date has passed. Amazon can shipping the day before the expected delivery date and still get it on time many times. I know to double check the expected delivery date on the checkout screen as that will show me the date and if I choose to procede, that means I accept that day. It does not mean I see the date but hope it arrives sooner and if it doesn't I throw a fit. Also, this delivery date will tell me if a third party seller is in another country. If the expected delivery date is a range of 2 weeks 3 weeks out, it is not in my country. Amazon does have some add on only items. These will only be able to be purchased with orders over $25 sold and fulfilled by Amazon. It can include all add on only items. These items aren't big sellers and cause losses by making them available to be a single item delivery. Instead of increasing the price, they offer it as an add on item. Would you drive 20 miles to the store to purchase a pack of gum? Most add on only items have a list of other sellers on the right hand side. These are either higher priced or have a shipping fee. Sometimes the add on only item will ship by itself if it's in a different warehouse than the other items. This doesn't make the add on only feature a waste. That means the entire order made shipping and handling it not be a loss for them. The rest of their customer service departments are not helpful. Reports aren't taken seriously and often ignored.  They allow abuse in their forums and also allow some very nasty posts to be posted as well as bullying and public shaming while removing the dumbest of things. There is a group of nasty, dirty, hateful old ladies and a some men that think these women are the fake photos they share who spend their entire day looking for reviews to make fun of. They then share them on the forums so others can go look and downvote that reviewer. They write nasty comments on the reviews and Amazon allows it. People should not be afraid to write reviews. Other forums are fool of the most disgusting posts with inappropriate language and subjects. Amazon allows in even though it looks horrible on their behalf. Is it that their reps don't understand English enough to know that eating poo isn't an appropriate topic. Also, Amazon allows fake profiles that are attacking sellers and products for no good reason. They write rude questions and reviews even though they don't own the products. With heaps of evidence sent to them, they still let these nutjobs play on Amazon. Lastly, Amazon is removing reviews and reviewing privileges of people they believe are violating their TOS but many people never violate their TOS and lose their reviews while people obviously violating their TOS and having been reported countless times are free to write their garbage reviews. Amazon priorities are a total crapshoot. After my Prime membership is up I am going to be cutting ties with Amazon because I won't be out anything. I can get my items elsewhere with no problem. They have gotten their priorities so out of whack lately and out sourcing their employees isn't helping them with these issues as they don't understand English when you contact them.

I am a Prime Amazon Member. I ordered a new $1300.00 TV that I found on Amazon which was promised to be delivered "next day" on July 6, 2016. The date was updated to July 7, 2016 online when I checked the status online. I called and was told that it would definitely be delivered on July 7th and that Amazon would refund my next day shipping. I waited all day on July 7th for the TV. The TV never arrived. I went online and it said that it was coming by MAIL and that it was in transit! I called Amazon and asked how in the world could they guarantee ANYTHING sent by MAIL to be delivered the following day...and how could they send something so expensive and fragile BY MAIL? They had no answer. The agent put me on hold and said that she would call the USPS about the delivery. She came back online and said that she had spoken with the USPS and had been told it would be delivered by 3:00 p.m. She told me that she would call me back at 4:00 p.m. to confirm the delivery. At 4:20 p.m., I had no TV and no call from Amazon. So, I called Amazon. All the agent could tell me was that, in checking his tracking information, he could see the TV was "in transit." I told him that I KNEW that much as I could see it when I looked myself. He told me at that point that the TV would "probably come tomorrow or the next day." I told him that I had reserved a man to come out to mount my TV based upon Amazon's "guarantee" and all he could say was, "I'm sorry. I know you are frustrated." At that point I told him to cancel the order and I would go to Best Buy and get the TV there for the same price. He told me that he canceled the order. I also told him to cancel my Prime Membership as well. I am done with Amazon and their delivery "guarantee" days which, obviously, mean nothing at all.  UPDATE: The Amazon Representative did not cancel the orde and it arrived the next day by mail carrier. I refused the delivery as I had already purchased the same TV from Best Buy the night before. The ironic thing about that was when the mailed TV arrived, the guy was at my home mounting the one I had bought at Best Buy! I'm still waiting for my refund from Amazon on my credit card of over $1300.00 and filed a dispute with AMEX just in case. Amazon says it can take up to two weeks to get the money refunded as returning the TV can take that long to get to them. They did give me $100.00 on my AMEX as a "goodwill" gesture for all the issues with this order. The Amazon representative also did not cancel my Prime as I had asked them to do. I seriously think that their representatives say "Yes!" To just about everything and understand very, very little English.

I had purchased a Toshiba 620 DVD/VHS Recorder. it arrived filthy, completely unusable and broken. I contacted Amazon and they gave me the go ahead to return it to the seller for a full refund. I also contacted Ace Internet Solutions, Inc. and was assured that I would receive a refund in full, which included the return shipping that I had to pay for out of my own pocket. For some unknown reason, Amazon refused to give me the refund that I am entitled to. I contacted Amazon via email several times and by phone as well. Amazon's Customer Service agreed that since I have proof that this piece of garbage is in Ace's possession along with my money - $152.00, that I am indeed entitled to a full refund. Instead, Amazon sent me an email stating that they were not going to give me a refund. I contacted Ace many time, was repeatedly promised a refund and never received anything. I went to the amazon site to buy a replacement catalytic converter for my vehicle to meet California emission standards. The site noted the converter would fit my vehicle. I ordered it, had it welded in place, and went for a smog test. It failed, and the emissions were 4 times higher with this new cat as compared to the old one. After further research, the converter Amazon noted for fitting my vehicle was incorrect. They allowed me to return it, but I had already spent the price of the converter on the installation and smog test. The vehicle is now listed as a gross polluter. WOW! GARBAGE IN GARBAGE OUT!

Amazon was great. Now it is terrible. A. They have become very sneaky, with a complicated order procedure that tries to trick you into signing up for Amazon Prime (my 91-year-old mother was a victim) by making the buttons for that bright orange, as if that is the default for ordering. The "free shipping" now is also obfuscated: It used to be at the top, now is in with "Free Shipping! - (if you get our credit card)". "Amazon Pantry" as well--what is that? Complicated. Sometimes I choose an item and it comes up in the cart that I ordered two (no, I didn't click twice). Sneaky. Don't like it at all. Used to be simple and quick. B. Shipping is now much less reliable, time-wise. They have taken to using the post office, which does not re-deliver, and tracking delivery dates are no longer accurate a lot of the time. C. Free shipping was $25 minimum order, then $35, now--apparently--$49. D. Aren't so great to their employees, from what I understand. I always look for an alternative (B&H for electronics, for instance). E. Amazon-shipped items still pretty reliable, but I have had increasing problems with outside store orders. Seems like they don't vet the stores so well anymore. I notice that many Amazon-affiliated stores are rated badly by Resellerratings. F. Customer service is like communicating with robots (which may be what you are doing). Returns have been fine for me, however. Amazon needs to take a page from Costco, which has held its quality--and continued to make a good profit--even though it is at the top in its field and treats its employees very well. I will avoid Amazon whenever possible.

I had a horrible time getting my New Yorker Kindle subscription moved to my Kindle Fire. Amazon said,"That's the Kindle people and they don't know what they're doing over there." Spent many more hours (literally) on hold and with Amazon and Kindle people who could barely speak English. Since January of 2014 to date, March 2016, we have placed 207 orders with Amazon. It has been, until now, an extraordinarily good experience. We have a great deal of respect for Mr. Bezos and what he has done. This particular experience, however, was awful! I thought that, since we had faired so well, maybe a larger item would work too; so, we ordered this Samsung dishwasher with installation and removal of the old washer. Words fail me. I had planned to aggregate all of the failures and miscommunications of this transaction like some prosecutor in a courtroom for others to read, but I am tired of thinking of it. So, here goes with an unstudied, less calculated recap: from the inception of the order we received multiple e-mailed correspondence as to the delivery of the product and the delivery of the ordered installation from at least four disparate sources. There have been at least six different business entities and Amazon agents involved in the entire process: (i) Plessers, whoever that is; (ii) AM Home Installation, or something like that; (iii) Amazon, of course, who by the way disavow any responsibility once the money has changed hands, choosing rather to turn both the work and all appeals for help over to various other amorphous agencies; (iv) Nathan at 800.344.4856 I have no idea how I came to be in touch with him, but at least to his credit he revealed surprise at how the order had aged; (v) some man from New York named Miguel Santos, who reluctantly later identified his agency as Infinite Installations and himself as customer service agent for Amazon, that I talked to with no good outcome (At one point, Mr. Santos sent me an e-mail with an Amazon telephone number to call for customer service; it turned out to be a non-working number); and not least (vi) the named agent now representing Amazon for the claim. From the beginning delivery was promised in the e-mails, but the installation dates supplied by each mail preceded the delivery date stipulated in the respective communication! In an e-mailed response, I asked how you could install a product not yet delivered, but never got an answer to that or any other question. With each mail, the delivery-install dates kept changing, each time with an install date which post-dated the delivery date! Finally, this AM company arrived 5 hours beyond the promised four hour window. I let the guy come into my home with the machine. He was clearly harried and seemed uncertain of himself. He brought the new machine into my home, banging our custom front door as he entered. When the subject of removal of the old dishwasher came up, the guy said they were not responsible for removal of the old washer. NOTE: THIS WAS ONE OF THE IMPORTANT PARTS OF THE AGREEMENT WE ENTERED WITH AMAZON! I then refused delivery and asked him to leave our home. At first he wouldnt leave. I insisted that he go. Miserable experience! The left hand seemed not to know that the right hand even existed, much less what it was doing. They have now charged us $600 and left us to deal with another third party for ostensible resolution, bringing the total of different involved parties to at least six. To anyone who might say to us that we should have known better, this is Amazon, we would say, you are absolutely right. We should have known better. We know now. Small purchases have been great for us, and we will continue to buy these items; we will avoid complex buys in the future, however simply they are presented. P.S. I was interested in seeing what kind of response we might get from other Amazon customers. In the main, I agree with what I have read: for small items, Amazon is great! Could not agree more fully. Thus far, however, no one has shared an experience substantially similar to ours that went well for them. Buying a $1200 dishwasher and having it installed in your home is not like buying a small commodity. Our experience was confusing and very disappointing. Amazon did not act as a third party overseeing the process to ensure good service. This is simply not true. P.S. (160407) We have the final disposition of this matter. We originally paid Amazon $1,131.00; of that amount Amazon returned to us $1,083.40, keeping $226.20. Post-Script #3 (160503) Before finding SiteJabber and making this post, I tried to first post this review on Amazon. Someone who did not identify themselves denied the review; their only comment lay in the following excerpt with quotation marks outlying:  "We have a great deal of respect for Mr. Bezos and what he has done." The intimation from this censor(s) seemed to be, we only accept complimentary reviews, seemingly suggesting that it would be ok for me to say nice things about them. That response set me on this quest.

Now I'm stuck with needing to order from amazon as they have the easiest access to products I like, and not wanting to give them any more $. As long as I make simple orders, I think it'll be ok......Never want to call in ever again.

Twice I've received used merchandise (directly) from Amazon.com, when it was supposed to be new. In a recent case, Amazon sent a used, defective backup camera system for Recreational Vehicle (RV), then replaced it with a 2nd defective unit. The instructions were useless. I cobbled together one working unit and returned the non-working parts. I installed the unit on my RV, which involved drilling holes in the body. Then I discovered that the camera had a condensation problem that arose whenever the camera was on for more than 15 seconds. I tried to contact the company (Ducooler and Xie Ju Ming) but their website was inactive. You can type them a support email, but you can never send it :-(  . Amazon agreed to take back the 2nd unit. When I sent it to Amazon, they charged me a $15.20 "restocking fee".  This is blatant fraud, as the unit was defective. Clearly Amazon intends to send it to yet another victim. Perhaps they hope that someone will pay for it, be confused by it, and not return it. Fraud, Fraud, Fraud.  I replied to the Amazon email telling me that they were "restocking" it, but it bounced. Their email wasn't even signed by a person. I disputed the insufficient refund with the credit card company and have no doubt that the dispute will stick, given the circumstances. Huge amount of time spent; some phone calls over 1 hour. Many emails sent. Bottom line is: Avoid Amazon.com, and if you do receive used merchandise instead of new merchandise, return it immediately. Don't waste time trying to make it work....chances are that it has already been returned by someone else.

I used to love amazon. It was great for buying and selling textbooks as well as buying other things at competitive prices. Over the last year, however, I have become very disappointed with the site. I spent hours Christmas shopping trying to find items that would fulfill a $25 credit for a "gift" item that my daughter really wanted. The qualifying items were considerably more expensive than other sellers had them for, and I ended up spending a lot more than I wanted and I ended up with a DVD that will not play on US players. Just recently, I tried to sell a few things on amazon. I couldn't log into my seller account and had to sign up for a professional account which costs $39 a month. I didn't know I could sign up for an individual account and sell my items that way. Long story short, I HAD to deactivate my account because I didn't have the correct tax or business info to have a professional account. Now I can't sell on amazon again unless I create a new account. I can't even cancel/terminate my existing account without contacting customer service. I can't even find the number to contact them to do so. The whole website has become so user unfriendly and not worth my time to continue to shop through them. I never liked ebay, but I'm thinking I will switch back to shopping there because amazon has just gotten too greedy and doesn't really care about consumer needs anymore.

I've enjoyed many years of great service with Amazon. The few minor problems I've encountered through the years were solved fast and efficiently by their Customer Support Team. Free standard shipping during this time was 5 to 7 days. It seems that with the introduction of "Prime" free standard shipping now takes 7 to 12 days. The last three items I've ordered took the proverbial slow boat to Missouri. One package took 5 days to get from Texas to Missouri. Then while tracking the package it was delayed for 5 days at a facility close to me. A helpful Amazon Rep had it delivered the next day. Ink for my printer has taken 7 days to get halfway from California to Missouri! I could walk faster than that! My impression is that those of us that use free shipping will be penalized. If poor shipping practices don't affect you, by all means continue to shop at Amazon. Stewart C. Hagerman Member: American Mensa Society

Amazon is demonstrating some true Holiday spirit with deceptive promotional offerings. So deceptive their own support people don't understand it. Watch out. Amazon will offer you $5.99 for Amazon Pantry items in exchange for accepting slower shipping options.  After 3 phone calls and nearly 1.5 hours on the phone, Amazon support was finally able to explain it. It's only works for a very limited number of grocery items that Amazon sells directly themselves. You'll know because "the item will be marked as an Amazon Pantry item." So I got two credits. About $10. I figured I would at least buy an item for free. I chose Vanilla extract for about $10. However, it was going to cost me $10 to get it. Doesn't make sense, right? Well, you can only use one credit at a time. So that means I can only use $5 to buy the $10 item. Then for any "pantry" items that Amazon sells you are charged $5 for a "boxing fee." Usually this is called shipping, and since I am an Amazon Prime Member, I expected my shipping would be free. Not the case. So in the end it would cost me $10 to get a $10 item as an Amazon Prime member, even with a $10 credit.

I ordered from an Amazon marketplace seller and was later told by email the item was not in stock and wouldn't be for a long time. I was given instructions for cancelling which I followed. Much later they charged my card and sent the item after I'd bought it elsewhere. They made me jump though a bunch of hoops to return it and then charged a 15% re-stocking fee. I complained to them and Amazon. Both said I had gotten the item so that was it. The package came from Overstock, not the seller. These marketplace sellers apparently merely put on a listing, jack up the price, order from somewhere else and apparently have no control over the stock info or the orders. The item was cheaper directly from Overstock and even cheaper ordered from Walmart. My advice is don't order from marketplace sellers unless it will be fulfilled by Amazon.

Amazon purchased audible.com and their actions have been very unethical in sharing Amazon account information with Audible in order to continue to debit accounts after members have cancelled memberships and/or their debit cards. DELETE your credit/debit card numbers from your Amazon account. While investigating i found that Amazon will try any account that you have ever used (if you haven't actually gone into account management and manually deleted them) if the card you authorized them to use is expired, cancelled, or otherwise not usable. I had used my mothers credit account at one point in time (as authorized) and would have been appalled had they started using her account for my husbands audible membership (although he never even signed up for a membership). It makes me wonder if they were able to use my amazon account info to pay for my husbands audible account, what is to stop them from getting into her amazon account and debit other accounts. The whole thing is mind boggling to me that they somehow got into my amazon account to pay his audible account and it seems like this Audible purchase by Amazon could have been for this express purpose to pursue other income opportunities by unsuspecting customers.

Unreliable and arrogant. These words describe what United Graphics has now become. I first contracted with UGI in 2009, and I found it to be timely and honest. My most recent experience with them has proven how this company has lost its way. I was told by a customer service representative named Abell that 575 books would be shipped the first Thursday in June for next-day delivery. I even paid money to have this shipment guaranteed. The next day, she calls saying that the shipment had not gone out, claiming that a printing machine had broken, even though she said that the books were being bound two days before. I then requested that one box of 56 books be shipped for Saturday, in time for a book fair I was working that weekend. She agreed, and then gave me the UPS tracking number. When I checked ups.com that night, the next-day shipment had been incorrectly processed for Monday, not Saturday morning. UGI then insults me further by offering me a five-percent credit -- credit...as if I'm going to use them again! -- on the job. Somewhere, this company has lost its dedication to customer service, honesty, and respect for its customers. Do yourself and your project a favor and avoid this company

Amazon.com's site promised I would get a phone call in 1 minute when I needed help sending an item I added to someone's gift list. They did not call in over 25 HOURS despite feedback I would get a call within 1 minute. They later refused to allow me to add a gift to someone's wish list and send it to them. My crime was wanting to send a Teddy Bear. I had spent hours on Amazon's site trying to add and then order a gift for an online friend who's address is known to Amazon via their wish list, in fact I had already ordered one item that was delivered so I couldn't understand why I could not get their site to work a second time. When I finally spoke to someone in customer service from the "wish list" department I was told that I can not add something to someone's wish list and send it to them. If that is the case, why do they even allow consumers to add "gift ideas" to the friend's wish list profile if you can't buy them? They told me it was because the recipient might want to return the gift, but I'm the customer, not the gift recipient. It's my money and I am buying a gift, not an item the recipient can return and get money in return. The only rationale I can think of is due to sending inappropriate gifts, however I was trying to send a Teddy Bear for a friend, to help in a trying time. Amazon's employee had ZERO interest in trying to understand. Stupid policy is what we have so we're going to follow it. That should be their Slogan. What is perhaps most ironic about the email I received from Amazon in response to my complaint is the last line of Amazon's email: "Your feedback is helping us build Earth's Most Customer-Centric Company." This has to be the biggest lie I've seen advertised by a company in years. What an absolutely horrible company to do business with.

I have shopped Amazon many times and have always been happy with it. I also sometimes have to rely on online shopping like Amazon because I am still recovering from cancer, and am not always able to jump in the car and drive a half hour to a major chain store to get what I need. So when I tried the new Prime Pantry I had high expectations of what it's quality would be, and was hopeful in it being a good resource for me. I ordered items that were canned and items in boxes, that I would normally buy in the grocery store, and thought I was getting a deal with such a decent price, but when I received my box of items I was really disappointed. First of all, the cans were almost all dented. Not normally a big deal, but there was never any mention of denting on the site, and Amazon is usually particular about making an honest accounting of the condition of items. The cans were packed loosely into the box with the boxes of food and pasta so they caused plenty of damage while getting bounced around by the postal service. The shipping box was split into 2 sides, but the cans were scattered so there were several on both sides so NONE of the boxed food was safe from damage. Some items were so damaged that they were leaking, and had to be thrown out. Since the service, Prime Pantry, shows you how full a box is when you are ordering, I was confused why there was so much looseness in the shipping box, when the service said the box was 99% full, when I ordered. I have alerted them to my disappointment, and they refunded my money in full. However, this service is not one that I am eager to give another try. I told Amazon that I would rather shop at the grocery store, and spend extra money, than use this service again and roll the dice on what I may have to throw out from damage. I do not want to go through this every time I get a box from them that is packed like the people working there are living brain donors. Who wants to deal with that?!

On Friday, April 17, 2015 before 8:00am, I placed 2 orders and paid additional money for next day delivery. Late Friday evening I received an email from Amazon that the items would be delivered at 8pm Saturday evening. As luck would have it, the items did not arrive. I contacted Amazon's Customer Service department shortly after 8pm Saturday evening. I spoke with a first line representative, a supervisor and manager to explain that my shipments never arrived which were gifts for my niece's birthday party on Saturday. I also explained that my niece waited all day to receive her gifts and was excited about her special day. All 3 Amazon representatives told me that the delivery date and time were estimates, and that the items would arrive on Monday, April 20. Nowhere did it mention that the overnight shipping was an estimate. The reason I asked for a manager is because the supervisor also said, "sometimes we get disappointed." This was unacceptable! I told her that adults understand, but children do not. Children are kids for a short time and look forward to birthdays and holidays. Had I known on Friday morning when I placed the order that delivery was going to be at 8pm not earlier in the day, I would have cancelled the order. Such information was sent via email late Friday evening and should have been noted during the ordering process. A delivery time should be available when an order is placed. Additionally, when the packages did not arrive by 8pm Saturday evening, I only learned by calling Amazon customer service that the packages would be delivered on Monday. Amazon did not take the initiative to notify me of the delayed deliveries. Had I known that the guaranteed delivery date which I paid additional shipping cost for had changed, I would have gone shopping either Friday or Saturday with my niece for her gifts. The Amazon representatives were insensitive to the situation and made excuses for the company. Their generous offer was to refund the guaranteed overnight shipping cost. Meanwhile, I still have no gifts for my niece. To say the least, I am extremely disappointed with my overall Amazon experience.
Every attempt to use Amazon has resulted in angry despair. You cannot ever get products sent outside the US. I have located the same companies direct, and no problem, go through Amazon... no way.

In 2014- based on the advertisement-and my conversation with their customer service representative- I bought from Amazon- a 10 inch foam mattress- made by Sleep Well. I was deployed for active military duty-and upon my return- I attempted to buy a frame. I was now told that any frame I bought-would require a wooden plywood-to be placed between the frame and mattress- to ensure the warranty- and not injure the sleeper. I contacted Amazon- and after they read the advertisement- we filed an A-Z Complaint. I never heard from anyone- besides my refund was denied. Meanwhile I spoke to Sleep Well-and under the circumstances they were sending me a replacement mattress. Amazon wrote me a thank you letter- and was sending it up via Corporate- because any frame sold by Amazon-made by Olee-Zanus etc- approximately 100 frames- are all falsely advertised- and all require that plywood board to be paced on the frame- this is no-where mentioned in any of their ads- so all 100 advertisements for these frames would have to be revised. Meanwhile A-Z without talking to me about anything denied my claim- even though Sleep Well was willing to replace the damaged mattress. At no charge. I asked Amazon to compensate me-for all the time-aggravation-and work that I performed- that permitted their organization to send this information up the ladder to Corporate-so that all these bed frames would have to be revised and corrected. I asked for compensation-for all my time and work- in the form of a metal frame-that holds a box spring- as to ensure the 10 year warranty of the mattress. After being put on hold for over 1 hour- so Indian Supervisor came back- and was rather rude- and objected in doing anything besides denying my claim. I have forwarded all these letters to Mr. Bezos- of course I don't expect him to respond- but possibly one of his subordinates after reading this fiasco- would make things right. In the last year- the Amazon catch phrase has become- if your not happy- return the product-and we shall provide you with a full refund. Great business practice. Must be nice when you are a monopoly.

And like most big companies today; there is nobody you can talk to; they simply don't want to hear about any customer complaints, unless it's on a list they provide.  They are also not cheap. The other day I was going to order a basketball pump from them; it was $4.95; with $6.75 shipping. I went to E-bay found the same pump, for the same price from a 5 star dealer, and the shipping was free. The Amazon seller wanted more for shipping, and handling then the item cost.  Amazon only gives you free shipping if you spend over $35.00. In my book that makes them yet another Corporate giant trying to get more out of you, then you should have to pay.  There are better deals on E-Bay then these rip off artists are trying to scam you with. They are sneaky! My wife ordered a vest for me on their website. There was no mention that this vest was coming from China until after you place your order.  The vest cost $20.00 with shipping. You know this is the worst buying experience I have had in my entire life and I'm 63 yrs old. I have had better experiences buy a used car then it was dealing with Amazon on this. First off I will never ever purchase another product from any of amazon's affiliates. When you sell a product you ought to have someone there that can answer questions on what the products limits are. Explained to the person what I was going to use the product for and they said it would do just fine. I also called the manufacturer to see what they said about it too and was told the very same thing. After I had 2 units both of them damaged and had to be repaired by me to make it look decent. Took me probably 2 hours to straighten the sleeves on the units. Without any compensation whatsoever for doing it. I could have called the service center and had them come out and fix it I guess but of course the nearest one is 4 hours away and that would have cost you guys a bunch of money but I fixed them myself. The worst thing about this whole deal is I bought the unit for a new building and there was a hole cut in my wall to fit this unit. Now when I find out the unit isn't anything close to what I need to do the job I wanted it to. I have a hole in my wall where a different product will not fit. So I have to have the contractor of the building to come out and replace a bunch of wains coating and insulation. This was not free so I not only did all the repairs on the unit taking it in and out of the building several times I had to get my building fixed. And then the returning of the product was another thing. You advertise this unit as being 150 lbs. and it was 195 lbs so UPS wouldn't ship it back to you. I got the first one all packaged up and they picked it up. The next day it was sitting on my front porch on it's top. I couldn't even get out of my door since the unit was placed in front of my door. So being 63 and having to try and move this 195 lbs package off my porch was another interesting undertaking. So had to go buy some 2x4's and build a ramp to get the package up and my truck. So there was another expense. The 2nd one was the same way, you sent a tag from UPS, they picked it up and brought it back the next day. I hope all your customers aren't treated this way or your company will go the way of your first phone a failure. If I can post this message on your website I surely will because this is totally an unacceptable way to do business in my opinion. I also very mad at all the run around I have been getting on getting the refund. Was told the first time the credit you gave me for the bent up sleeve was compensation for the work done on the unit and the full price would be credited back to me if I didn't want to exchange it but that was another fib I guess because it sure wasn't. I'm sure no one will read this unless I can post it on Amazon's website someplace or somewhere I can give you a rating on your business.  Thanks for nothing, thanks for all the run around and thanks for all my added expense to get heat in my building.  Tim

Even if you can put aside the horrible treatment of Amazon employees, even if you can overlook the fact that Amazon is killing brick and mortar (along with all those retail jobs), this company is still horrible. There customer service is a joke. Fraud runs rampant now. I'm a savvy shopper and still got scammed twice in the last few months.  First ordered a Nintendo Switch was charged and received a tracking number that never moved. It took Amazon far too long to refund the obvious scam. Second time I got a fake 200 GB SanDisk micro SD card. It looked like a legit 200 GB card, but was just blank plastic on the backside and was actually only an 8 GB card. Again Amazon was slow to refund and amazingly didn't even close down the scam sellers account. I then received an Amazon gift card as a gift from my aunt that had a zero balance on it when I tried to use it. Amazons response was basically too bad so sad. They said, "It appears someone other than the intended recipient used the gift card. We cannot offer a refund." Gee that's nice, and when I asked who used the card they said that info is private. They admit the card was fraudulently used, but then hide who did it and do no further investigation. No wonder scams run rampant on Amazon, their rules literally promote scammers. That was the final straw, I cancelled a huge Christmas order I had placed as well as my Prime membership. The funny thing is Amazon actually isn't always the cheapest, they've just brainwashed us all into thinking it.  I ended up becoming a Gamers Club Member at Best Buy and reordered all the Christmas stuff even cheaper than it was from Amazon and felt good supporting a brick and mortar store and the sales associates who depend on that job. Amazon is a horrible company that is getting so big they believe they don't have to care about anyone. Stop supporting this company, or in the future we will all be forced to work for Amazon and buy from Amazon, as they will have fulfilled their evil plan and put all brick and mortar stores out of business.

I believe Amazon is involved in fraud. They seem to have a glitch in their online ordering system that causes you to order items that you do not want. I was ordering two books, but had others in my shopping cart, I selected a quantity of 0 on the items that I did not want. The only step to proceed from that page was to place the order, and the items that I had select as 0 quantity where ordered. Immediately afterwards I cancelled the order! Dont buy from Amazon seller Stores123. I bought this as a Christmas present for my fiance who likes modern furniture. I received the item and upon unpacking it, it seemed as though it had already been unpacked. The box was tattered and the packing tape had been retaped. Once I opened the product, I inspected it and found the underside fabric was torn where there was a piece of the wood frame supporting the center. It was not a large tear but it was a tear never-the-less. I decided that it was likely a used product sent by mistake so I repacked it immediately. Given that Christmas was a few days away, I went to a local furniture shop and found something similar to buy in time for Christmas. I bought the product because it was on Amazon so I felt comfortable. I do understand Amazon uses 3rd party sellers and the return policy for this seller seemed straight-forward: if the product is damaged, they buyer can return it for a full refund. The seller has been trying to get the 15% restocking fee from the beginning of my communication with them. I dont think I should have to pay $100+ to them because they sent me a used product by mistake. They are claiming that there is no tear on the bottom fabric but that is absolutely not true and I am surprised they would blatantly lie like that. They have even sent me photos they took upon return of the product and the tear is shown (again, it is not big, but it is there and it is something I would consider as damage and would buy off a classified bulletin board). At this point, I have requested them to refund me 100% of what I paid and I have disputed the charge through my credit card issuing bank. Stores123 have not replied to me with any message indicating they will provide me a 100% refund. They have offered to send me the product back (which I clearly do not want) or to pay a 15% restocking fee. I really feel extorted here as they are in clear violation of their return policy.

I had purchased from them for the last 12 years and had no problem. However, I recently bought an electronic item and needed it returned. Amazon sided with the seller. The seller agreed to the return, e-mailed me that it received the item back and refused to refund money. Amazon knew this, had Post Office Delivery proof, and only sent protected e-mails to the seller. When this didn't work, Amazon refused to help me.  On my own I had to find out Sellers address and phone number and contact them. They claimed I wasn't in their system at all and never heard of the company that shipped it. I told them the 3 names the Corporation was registered as being under, the two addresses, and the Presidents' name. I told them I would be contacting the State Attorney's Office for fraud, US mail order fraud, and credit card fraud, etc. They hung up on me. The next day Amazon credited my charge. I will never use Amazon again. They still allow this company to sell on their site knowing they are frauds.

Great everytime! Much better than eBay which has the worst customer service, Amazon has alway been great to buy from and to deal with! I recommend Amazon.com to anyone shopping online. They are really great.

Horrid customer service! I recently bought an iPod touch from Amazon (the actually site, not a reseller listed on the site) and recently got a phone call from them saying I now owe a collection agency $275 for the iPod (note, this call was from Amazon, NOT the agency). After the first call this morning (November 3rd) I called Amazon back to ensure this wasn't a spoof of some sort (seeing as the number was 5 digits). After talking to Amazon the first time, I was told that the reason I owe money was that I did not have the funds needs to pay for the iPod when they tried to charge me yesterday (November 2nd). I was also told that they had contacted my bank-which, after a talk with my bank, they didn't do-to ensure I had the funds needed at the time of ordering (October 20). After the explantion of Amazon's poor charging times, I was told to contact the collection agency to talk to them. So I did. I couldn't get in touch with them [the collection agency] so I called my bank for suggestions on my next step. I was told to call Amazon back, which I did. After having to explain to them [Amazon] what I was told earlier, I was contacted to a three way call with myself, the Amazon rep, and a rep from the collection agency. The agency was rather gruff with me, but I was rather pissed, and was trying to get a simple answer out of the Amazon rep who was still on the line: why did you send me an iPod without being paid(To me, this seems like a horrible business trait)? Instead of an answer to that, I was told that my account number (since I "paid" for the iPod directly from my bank account) must have been typed wrong. To which I asked why Amazon didn't tell me at the moment of this realization on their part. All said and done, I will NEVER use Amazon again. I realize I am only one person not using a multi-national company, but due to this terrible way of dealing with not only their customers, but their money.

It's easy to get lured in by the cheap prices for new hard cover books. But I feel they have gone too far. I mean, you can buy anything from baby wipes to a tire iron. Why does it need to be so big? And when I had a problem with a merchant who overcharged me (some sort of clerical error on THEIR part) over 8 times what I was quoted to pay it took me nearly 3 months to clear it up. There is no phone number to call and talk to a live human being and I had to send email after email to try to clear it up. It was ridiculous.  But let's focus on their book review section for a moment: I really hated a book and gave it one star. The author harassed me using various aliases and, then worst of all, got Amazon.com to pull me one star review AND I was accused of hectoring this author. All because this one little crybaby (named Paul Cohn...look it up...I kid you not) complained. And what I found especially fascinating about this particular author is that besides writing total crap "novels" he attacked everyone who gave his book anything less than 5 stars and ALL of his 5 star reviews were from "people" who had never written another book review in their LIFE! I mean... it wasn't a best seller... it maybe sold 20 or 30 copies and it has about 10 5 star reviews that these reviewers have NEVER written another single book review.  I mean, if that doesn't reek or sound of fish, I don't know what does. And Amazon comes down on me??? well, that's just crazy. I say skip Amazon.com and buy local (even though I do live in Seattle, so Amazon is local for me)...because there are so many other book stores who deserve your business.  And don't even get me started on their secondary market. I recently purchased a book that was said to be in "like new" condition. When I got it the cover was torn, there was a red wine (I hope it was red wine) stain on it and worse of all!!! Some passages in the book were underlined in pen! So I complained 3 weeks ago and they said they would refund my money...but have they? ope. And I'll bet you anything it will take between 10-15 emails to get them to honor their money back guarantee. That was 3 weeks ago, and I have not received an email saying that my money was refunded. I would say this is the ONLY time I would ever say: Set fire to Amazon! (because I associate that name with a particular rain forest that is in peril). Plain and simple: they suck...long, hard and completely.

I have had a Amazon buying account for years now, mostly buying books and mp3's with relative satisfaction. I had always sold strictly on Ebay.com for 4 years now and have always been happy with my experience there. So last week I decided I would try selling on Amazon. I set up my seller account, listed 5 items for sale and figured that would be it. I'd check it every day to see if any of my items sold. The next day I checked it and to my surprise, Amazon stated that they had suspended my account because of policy violations. Upon further inspection I found out that they had suspended my account because they had linked my account to another suspended seller account. I thought this must be a mistake as I don't have nor have I ever had another amazon account. Nor does anyone living in my household, ie my girlfriend. After emailing amazon and explaining this I received a form generated email back from them stating that while they could not share any info on how they relate accounts or what account I am supposedly related to they had significant proof that I was linked to another account. After many emails I finally called there customer service and was told in exact words, there was nothing they could do to help me. I asked if there was a superior I could talk to or anyone who could help me and was told no, that department does not respond by phone. At this point I was getting very frustrated, and after a few more emails back and forth, with every single amazon response being another form generated email, I finally contacted the better business bureau. Well, alot of good that did. Amazon gave them the same bulls&*t response they gave me. So I asked, if someone is using my name, bank account etc, shouldn't they tell me what this so called account is I am linked to so I can put a stop to. Well, Amazon does not give any info on how they link accounts, I'm just supposed to take there word for it that I am linked to another account. Finally I contacted amazon to close any and all accounts related to my name and after probably 10 emails and 4 or 5 more phone calls, all just to get my damn account closed, because I WILL NEVER, EVER , EVER shop their crap website again, I finally managed to get my account closed for good. I don't know who the hell amazon thinks they are but this is one website I will never be visiting again. I have sold on Ebay for 4 years now and have a 99.7 percent rating on there, and have never encountered anything like this at all. If I have to call Ebay, I am always able to talk to a live person who usually can solve my problem in a matter of minutes. Amazon has poor customer service at best. AT BEST! I am not the only one with complaints like these either, google AMAZON SUCKS and look at all the pages. Amazon is not the first website that I would order an item from. Amazon has a tendency to deliver packages days after it was scheduled for delivery .Sometimes they don't even ship your package until the day that it was supposed to be delivered to you. If it's an important item that you drastically need in a hurry I suggest shopping somewhere else. They are sometimes very unreliable, their customer service can use some improvement, and their delivery times are usually unpredictable to say the least.  I ordered lights to decorate my dorm room off of amazon and I never received my order from them. When I first ordered it they told me that it would come within 4 to 5 business days: however, that was not the case. My lights did not ship until the 4th day of me waiting for them. I waited a couple days to see if my package would come. After about three days of not receiving my "shipped" package I decided that it was time to take matters into my own hands. I first called the delivery company that was supposed to drop off my package and they said that they never got a package for my address or name. I then decided to email amazon and they replied back saying that my item was shipped to the postal service that would be delivering it. Although, they said that my items were shipped I still did not receive them days later so I decided to call the company to and find out why. The first time I gave them a call I was on hold for at least 30 minutes waiting to talk to a representative. After being on hold for a significant amount of time, I was told that there were no available representatives to talk to at that time and that I should call the next day. The next day when I called I was on hold for a while but I finally got to talk to someone about my order. I was told that my order had been sent back because of an unknown error. I never got an email or notification saying that the order that I have been waiting on for weeks was sent back. When I asked why my order got sent back the representative told me that she was not sure why but sometimes it just happens. When I asked for my money she told me that I had to email amazon or go to the website and click on "about refunds" and ask back for my money there. So I emailed amazon and asked them for a refund due to the fact that my package got canceled but I never got my money back. The next day they emailed me and said they would refund me my money back within 24 hours of my initial email. I waited for the money but it never went back into my account so I emailed them again and this time they didn't respond until days later saying that, once again, they would send my money back to me. After not receiving my money a second time I just decided not to worry about it and just decided to be cautious of where and what I buy online. Next time I know not to rely on Amazon so much for my online shopping. Next time I know to be cautious and what sites I shop on. If you do decide to shop on Amazon just be mindful of what you get and who the seller is that you are getting the product from.

Amazon used to be this amazing company from a customer standpoint, but now that it has shut down most of its competition and continues to grow, the company is starting to tank. Prime is no longer Prime as you're paying more for it and receiving less. Two day shipping is a lie, it's more like 4 or 5 day or whenever they feel like it shipping. Returns are more difficult to make and their product pricing is steadily increasing. The media and entertainment portion is a joke. This includes both the tv and music portion. I have increasingly found better products and prices fro other companies and I am seriously considering cancelling my Prime membership. After all, what's the point if you're paying for shipping by paying a higher price and receiving it days later than the "guaranteed" delivery date?

Mind you, NONE of the drivers bother to knock on the door or ring the doorbell and most do not read my instructions clearly posted next to my front door. For years I've been a regular Amazon.com Prime customer, and had once found their offerings and customer service both to be (past tense) terrific. During these past 6 months however I've observed some changes in the customer experience of this "customer centric company"; several of my orders now arrive minus total quantities, fragile items are not packed well at all or arrive completely damaged, and some missing orders only arrive after a follow up email is sent to Amazon.com Founder, Chairman, and CEO Mr. Jeff Bezos. In one recent month, 10 of my orders have arrived in an abysmal state; upon a review of each parcel it was not the fault of the shipping company.  In the interim, Amazon Prime Movies that were once available for no fee to paying Amazon Prime members are now available for additional fees.  All the while, Amazon.com has raised its annual Amazon Prime Fee to $119.: "Amazon is justifying Primes 20 percent price hike, to $119 a year, by saying it is more a valuable service than when the fee last rose four years ago" https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/business/wp/2018/04/27/how-to-get-around-amazon-primes-new-119-fee/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.ca2d4aa7a96 Amazon.com, customer centric or ego centric? https://slate.com/business/2018/04/amazon-earnings-and-a-media-narrative-thats-out-of-control.html

I used to LOVE Amazon. Recently however I have noticed some changes that I'm not very happy with. MOST RECENTLY: Prime Pantry - Apparently, NOW, you get a 30 day free subscription. After that you pay $4.99/month to use it? So, I already pay Amazon Prime $99/year, and now you want me to pay $60 more for Prime Pantry? Am now checking out Walmart.com, Target. com, etc.... I may be on the verge of ending Amazon's and my relationship.

I have bought a few dozen items and have some issues with their practices. Sellers on ebay virtually always ship out next day. So why a week stalling my orders, EVERY time? I can only conclude its to force customers using free shipping to join amazon prime. So I did. Or at least wanted to. I check the box for free 30 day membership and placed an order using my debit card. A couple of hours later I get an email and it says my order cant be shipped because my debit card turned down the $100 prime membership fee. Huh? The terms and conditions of prime free trial clearly state that amazon charges you the $100 at the END of the 30 day trial. And thats if you want the year of prime. Guess they lied. I ordered the same item from ebay. No problems. I guess they figure most people will take prime anyway after the trial and not notice they were billed a month earlier or figure fighting them for a refund if they dont is futile. Dishonest company.
