I feel compelled to update my review in light of Amazon's rotten service as of the past six months or so. Most of my supposed 2-day delivery orders never make it in two days, if I receive them at all (which then necessitates phone calls on my end to Amazon). The delivery companies have even posted pictures of other people's houses and claim that our house is where they delivered our packages. I've also received wrong merchandise that Amazon wanted ME to pay for to return! The delivery services they use are THE WORST!! Most of the time, our packages are either shoved into our mailbox or set beside it AT THE CURB, some of them getting soaked by the rain (I'm sorry that we live on a private drive, but for $99 per year for Prime, I expect better service). But the worst situation was recently when, on Amazon's own website in the My Orders section, it was stated that a Prime Pantry order of mine (my first order with PP, by the way) had been delivered 8 DAYS BEFORE WE ACTUALLY RECEIVED IT!! Not to mention that it had been placed, again, next to our mailbox, IN THE POURING RAIN! A neighbor called and told us that she saw it. The products inside that were in cardboard boxes were damp, but luckily nothing was ruined. The first person with whom I spoke at Amazon had to transfer me to another department (after dealing with ANOTHER order of mine that had been claimed on Amazon was delivered, as well, but was not). The second woman was VERY nice and said that Amazon is aware of all of the delivery problems and is working on it. I did end-up getting the choice of a refund or another box of them same items delivered for free, as well as have my $7.99 shipping cost returned (yeah, that even made it worse - the fact that I had PAID almost $8 to have THIS kind of service >:-( ). It's interesting how the free box of items showed-up the next day on my doorstep :-/ . Anymore, I try to find what I need on ANY other website and only go to Amazon for what I can't get anywhere else. I really don't know how much longer we'll keep our Prime subscription. Some other company needs to throw their hat in the ring and knock Amazon off its pedestal!

I really used to like Amazon, but a few recent experiences are making me reconsider my Prime membership, or doing much business with them at all. First, I had ordered some items for Christmas~ I ordered on December 18th, and they were due on the 20th. Then I get an e-mail saying the package would be delayed, and they were due on the 22nd. Christmas Eve morning, I contact them by chat and tell them I am hosting a holiday party in a few hours and still don't have the package. They again tell me that it is "delayed", that it is "lost in transit" but they assure that I will get the package by the end of the day (I did not), and they will refund the amount. I ask if I will still get the items if I am refunded, and that representative says that I will. Christmas morning, I contact them again and they say the package was lost, and that I need to reorder the items, but that negates the refund I was credited. I ask what they are going to do about the fact that my original package was never received, and the Christmas items we were waiting for will be arriving well after Christmas. They tell me that they will give me a credit of $5 to use towards my next order (then they say they will make it a $15 credit). However, we just recently placed an order, and I'm pretty sure they did not apply any credit to it. The second issue is that they charged our daughter's student card (which she had registered under our account so she could get things she needs for school) for our Hulu subscription. I asked why her card was suddenly charged when it has always been charged to the same card. They tried to say that there was not sufficient funds on our card, so that is when they charged hers. I checked our account and there were enough funds in our account when they charged her card. I told them that they should have given us notice if there were insufficient funds instead of going ahead and using her card, and that they should refund the amount to her, which they said they were going to do. But today they send an e-mail saying they are not able to refund the amount to her card! I told them that is not acceptable, so we shall see what happens after this.  I definitely notice a decline in their customer service from previous years. It used to be if there were any issues (which were rare), they were resolved quickly and with limited contact. Now I've had two negative experiences in less than a month of each other, I got bounced around between at least 5 different representatives last time, and the representatives try to placate you while telling you they cannot really help you (and it is not easy to understand what they are saying, the messages are in broken English). I have seen several people on other review sites saying that they have been told that 2- Day Shipping no longer applies (even though that is what they advertise and you pay for)....if that is the case, what is the point of having a Prime membership?

I have attempted to order stuff three times from Amazon. Bad news every time. First time it took several months to arrive. When I got it, I realized why. It had been sent by surface mail from Finland (to me in Canada). Second time I ordered from Amazon it arrived two weeks after the promised date. But by the time it arrived I had already been refunded after my complaint. The third time I attempted to order from them was last week: When I entered my order for an item costing $20 their system told me if I ordered at least $35 of stuff I would get free shipping. So I changed my order to double the amount of the identical product from the same supplier. When I did that they then said I had to order over $50 to get free shipping, and when I increased my order, again, this time to $53, at the check out they added $20 more to cover shipping. I cancelled the order, and when I complained they tried to shift the blame to the shipper of the goods, when it had been THEIR ordering process that had been making the promises of free shipping. In two words: silly deceit. I doubt I will waste any more time trying to order stuff from Amazon in the future.

I don't even know where to start with this review. I think anyone who's paying attention would see there are cheaper and easier places to shop, but clearly people simply shop for convenience these days. Not to mention they're building a complete Monopoly and yet paying zero federal taxes. In my opinion Amazon is everything that's wrong with our culture. We don't typically shop there anyway but were recently gifted an item from a prime member. This experience has been a catastrophe from start to finish: - First, the price jumped $9 from the time I found the item to the time they were ordered, which was about 24 hours. - item arrived and sizing was completely off. - This was a gift, yet I was told exchanges are not allowed unless the item is defective and you're exchanging for the EXACT same size, color, etc. So they would send a return label then send a gift card once the item was received. - item shipped back quickly and the card was sent to my email...for the cheaper price of the item, NOT the price that was paid for it. - I emailed customer service, who said "well, send us the original order number and we'll look into it." (Obviously I'd provided the original number when I requested the return. But, fine, I'll play their games. At this point I've already decided I won't be doing business with them ever again. I'm just trying to get through it to get my son his birthday gift!!) - I did a customer service chat, and was told sure they'd send the remaining balance, although they had actually charged us (the gift recipient) for return shipping and subtracted it from the value of the gift!! Unbelievable. - We just realized they sent the shipping fee to the original sender, so my son is still short $9 on the value of his gift. The prime member who sent the gift suggested we just send her the gift card number and she'll reorder the correct size. This is far too many hoops to jump through to send or receive a simple gift. We will not be doing business with them again.

Amazon used to be great, and was my go to site for ordering anything online. However in the last few times I ordered from them, my packages were delivered by "flex drivers." I live in a building with locked doors to the lobby that require a key to get in. In the past the mail people would just put my package in the mailbox or leave it by the door for me. But these flex drivers don't have keys and would ring my bell over and over and over and over. When I got downstairs some Joe Schmo off the street is holding my package, rudely shoving it at me and running away. The first time it happened I thought my package was sent to a neighbor across the street by mistake and he was pissed about it. He acted like I really inconvenienced him and pissed him off. But after 3 more incidents I did some research and realized that these random people are handling my packages, and every single one of them has been completely RUDE. Maybe it's just the area I live in, but not one of them has been polite and I don't appreciate being disturbed. I don't want strangers off the street handling my stuff and ringing my doorbell over and over again. I live on the 3rd floor, have a small child and work from home. It's not convenient or an enjoyable experience to order from Amazon anymore, which is a shame. I used to love Amazon prime but I will never resubscribe to it until they get rid of these flex drivers and only let professionals handle packages. And I haven't missed them at all. I can get the same stuff from ebay, often cheaper with free shipping without the hassle or subscription fee. Prime TV isn't worth it either. There's only a few shows and movies you can watch and they charge you for the good stuff. You have access to about 10 crappy kindle books that no one wants to read. Not worth the $99 bucks IMO.

Amazon used to be my first choice when making a purchase online. Great selection, good prices and fast shipping. But that's all changing. Over the past year or so i have noticed that Prime shipping is no longer 2 days but mostly 3-4 plus packing is taking 1-4 days so a 2 day Prime shipment can turn into 7 days or more. The actual packing has become very bad, a recent delivery of books have been thrown in with tools or other items without any protection, resulting in a book that looks decidedly second hand before they have even been used. I never used to have to return items but this year about 15% of all my orders have arrived damaged. Prices used to be the best but with a little Google search I'm find better deals on other sites and now that Amazon has decided to start charging tax on all sales, other sites are looking so much more appealing. As other reviewers have stated Amazon is getting too big and losing sight of its roots.

Amazon has decent prices for Prime members and if you can't locate something specific in your town, Amazon is easy. Unfortunately, too many fakes have taken over. I ended up with a knockoff Kylie lip gloss that caused a rash, knockoff vitamins and a supplement I bought there gave me an allergic reaction. Turned out it was sawdust mixed with something called "white cut." (I know a lab tech in FL, sent her a pill to test for me.) There are more Chinese knockoffs on there than not for everything including top name brand stuff. I ended up with a shampoo "sold by" a regular shelf brand here but ended up with a really weird knockoff -packaging and all. Amazon has started putting all products of the same labeling into one big bin. If you buy Olay face cream, you may end up with one by Olay or one of the infamous knockoffs -regardless of who you bought it from and what you paid. It's called "big boxing." Shop with caution.

My last review of Amazon was favorable. However, Amazon's Customer Service, which was once the best in the industry, is now among the worst in the industry. Representatives are most often in foreign countries, extremely difficult to understand, and argumentative. Amazon's procedure of telephoning you in response to your Email request is no more. Contacting Amazon Customer Service is a maze of screens that provide neither Email or telephone number direction. (Amazon Customer Service can be reached toll free at: 1-866-216-1072, but do not anticipate cooperation or assistance.)  Allowing that one of their primary competitors now offers two day free shipping on many orders, in addition to free to store shipping, Amazon's dramatic reduction in customer service is not well timed. Amazon needs to use their drones to examine their customer service.

I will continue to do business with them yet on a restricted basis. Unsure if they bought or just formed a strategic alliance with synchrony bank which issues their Prime Store Card. I've been shopping on Amazon almost since their inception back in 1994. My overall experience for the past 20-years has been great. I've had a seller and a buyer account. I've purchased hard to find items at very competitive prices. Up until the past year I've had absolutely no issues. Notably, over the past two-years Jeff Bezos has contracted outside of the USA (Amazon was a Seattle based company) and invested literally BILLIONS of dollars in India. Wow! Not only do I disagree with that (US companies should keep jobs in the US, this is totally selling out), but there's a reason labor is cheaper in India - it's of a lower quality. This is my story. I had signed up for the free 6-month Amazon Prime Student membership. For some reason I forgot to cancel it after the 6-month trial and the $49 membership fee was deducted from my account (no pre-warning this was about to happen). As I didn't want Prime membership I contacted Amazon and cancelled the Prime membership. Two weeks later the same thing happened - another $49 deducted from my bank account for Prime membership. Why? I have no idea. I didn't sign up for Prime again. Not only could this have sent my bank account overdrawn but it was an unauthorized withdrawal of funds from my bank account. Wow! That's usually referred to as 'theft'. I decided to close my Amazon account completely as I did not want to risk this happening again. Now, if you ever want to close your Amazon account you will see that there are no less than 7-steps, plus an email verification process, and then a 24-hour wait with no confirmation email that your account has actually been closed. The process is so convoluted it is literally designed to make closing your account extremely difficult. What a low-ball tactic to keep you. During the process I went online and 'chatted' with customer support. The customer support person I spoke to (Guarab) had a very poor command of the English language and did not offer anything helpful at all. Why would he? He's on the other side of the planet and English is not his first language. I did some research and sure enough (search it up yourself - I just used Wikipedia) between 2014 and 2016 Amazon invested over $5 BILLION DOLLARS in India!!!!  Wow!!! So, Jeff Bezos apparently isn't rich enough (despite his net worth of over $72 BILLION DOLLARS!!!) that he has to take jobs to India instead of investing here in America where he lives and where Amazon was birthed. I despise companies that do that. They're sell outs.  I would have given Amazon a one star review but I'm actually trying to be fair. They served me well for 20-years. It's only been the past year that they've really let me down and, in my opinion, sold out.  Ironically, Jeff Bezos money making strategy of investing in India (let's be honest - it's not because India is a beautiful country, it's exclusively because of the cheap labor force) has backfired on him because now he's lost my custom for life! The few dimes he hoped to save by hiring cheap (and ineffective) labor from India has actually cost him his customer base (in my case at least). Greed is a terrible thing Jeff. You can't take any of it with you. Thanks for selling out.

At the beginning this site was one of the best ecommerce. Good prices, good service and wonderful customer service. But in the last couple of year it has being awful. They don't have control of their vendors anymore. Any one can sell anything and deliver when they want and they cover themselves saying that you have a month to receive the merchandise. You don't see the estimated delivery date until you are completed your purchase. Last year I was going to school and ordered a text book for a class that was starting in 2 weeks. Schools constantly change text books and don't let you know what they are using with much time. After I finished my course (a month later) I hadn't received my text book and I had to cancel my transaction with my credit card. I couldn't easily find the customer service number in the page. As I was student from an accredited university I registered for the Student Prime account, but they logged me in a trial version of Prime that expired after 3 months. When I called them they said they couldn't correct the classification of my membership until a year later so I couldn't use the benefit of being student as they advertise. Be careful with this site. Good luck.

I've been using Amazon for years as both a buyer and a seller. Over the last couple of years their shipping has gotten worst and worse and so has their customer service. Amazon does take returns, but shipping it back is a huge hassle and nobody ever bothers to apologize for wasting my time when they send me a broken item. There is nobody held responsible and there's no way to contact them directly if I want to ask for them to package a delicate item more appropriately. On top of the broken items and extra slow shipping, I've recently been locked out of my account because of security issues that they will not clarify. I've called their customer service- and they've been incredibly useless, namely because they're outsourced oversea. Nobody will tell me why I can't get into my account. They tell me they don't know and another department will handle it. I ask to speak to that department and they say they will contact me. It's been days and I've heard nothing. If I didn't have a gift card balance, I'd likely just forget about my account and be done with them. Amazon is a soulless corporation that is responsible for the loss of countless jobs. Saving two or three dollars just isn't worth dealing with them. Support somebody that has a face and cares about their customers instead.

Remember when Amazon gave free shipping at any $25 orders? You've probably noticed that's no longer possible, unless you sign up for Prime. Prime in itself is probably a decent offering; however, not everybody needs or wants it, and therefore you get dinged in shipping costs. (shame on you!) That aside (as I could go on for a while), the main complaint here are sellers using Amazon to sell their goods, let's say used books. These sellers blame Amazon for not allowing them to combine shipping. Is that true Amazon? Where is your voice in all of this? Shipping is $3.99 flat rate for books. Anyone who's ever used USPS Media rates knows that you can ship printed material pretty inexpensively--less than $3.99. If this is true that Amazon won't 'ALLOW' combined shipping, then Amazon is looking for trouble in reduced sales. Just talking locally here with many people who used to use Amazon exclusively, I can tell you they have found other avenues. Also, these sellers put themselves on Amazon.com under multiple different names and then combine shipping for themselves, but never pass on those savings to you, the buyer. Where is Amazon's voice in all of this deceit? Do you like having them try to slip this by you? I think more and more people are going to revert back to buying locally, because the entire online marketing is becoming more dishonest and more of a scam. Keep your eyes open buyers!

When you search for an item, you can waste hours finding what you want, because there is no policing of the rules. You can get literally thousands of hits that have nothing to do with the keywords you entered. In order to search by price, you must select one of Amazon's often pointlessly similar categories. Then, often, you will get literally thousands of entries that are identical. For many items, you will get thousands of entries that have price $0.01, accompanied by shipping costs of, for example, $10.00. This makes searching by price futile. If you want to skip over these thousands of rule violators, you can't do it because Amazon only lets you skip ahead 2 pages. (Not only that, but they won't let you see more than 25 items per page.) They ought to let you enter the number of the page you want to visit next. I have complained to Amazon numerous times about this, pointing out that the experience at their competitor Ebay, for example, is much better. I have threatened to file criminal complaints against them for being a nuisance. They don't care. The next step would be to be to get millions of Amazon visitors to file complaints with the Federal Trade Commission and state attorneys general, requesting that Amazon be declared a public nuisance and a public health nuisance, and requiring Amazon to meet reasonable and customary standards before transacting any further business.

The one main problem I have with Amazon is their "fixed" reviews. 90% of the time when I write a 1 star review about any of their products, they REFUSE to publish it until I say something nice. They protect their SELLERS not their BUYERS, and this will eventually come back and bite them in the rear. They appear to be in the market to control the entire online experience which is good and bad. When their investors were paying for the services (their stocks skyrocketed even though they rarely showed profits), they could afford to do this. But now that investors are starting to demand some sort of steady profitability and some return on their investments other than inflated stocks, Amazon looks like they are starting to worry and this is why they tend to manipulate buyer reviews. If you don't believe this, try it yourself. Buy what you would consider a poor product and write a bad review. Fortunately, at this point you will get a refund from Amazon, but your review will most likely be squashed.

Amazon is really broken down into two categories:  1) customer 2) entrepreneur  As a customer, I've found good deals but recently I was what one could say as "screwed over." I ordered a book on July 22 which was supposed to be delivered by Sep 5. The book never showed up and I had to wait until October 2 to get it!  As an Entrepreneur, I have a webstore on Amazon which has proved to be a nightmare. Firstly, inventory between .CA and .US is considered separate. So in order for your products to climb the page rankings, although you have listings that pertain to both Canada and USA, only sales from each country will help you climb your rank-individually. This makes it extremely competitive.  Also, setting up the page was very difficult. There was no customer service. The account manager simply told me to watch a "tutorial." What is he/she getting paid for?  It turned out that all my inventory got sent to Amazon's warehouse where they ended up losing the inventory, and once found, refused to store it for Amazon fulfillment, because our product bottles where "oversized,"-something they did not worn use about beforehand!  The point is, as customer buying products Amazon is decent, but as someone trying to sell products (business seller's account), make sure you do your homework in advance and DO NOT rely on your account manager to help you out!

(Fifth update.) I've been purchasing from Amazon fairly heavily for years, not because I think it's the best source for merchandise (although it often is) but because its gift cards are the reward of choice for my participation answering queries for helpowl.com [which I've also reviewed for SiteJabber]. Pluses: 1. Price. Prices are generally excellent, and some purchases are tax-free. Many items are "eligible for free shipping," meaning that Amazon will not charge for shipping such items if their total price in one order is $25 or more.  2. Return policy. Return policies are easy and quite generous, and with items shipped by Amazon the company pays for return shipping, or may even waive the need to return the item at all. 3. Promptness. Shipping is always prompt, even when free. Minuses: 1. Support. I've now downgraded my star rating because of the increasingly terrible customer service. The good news is that phone support is usually, perhaps always, available. The bad news is the quality of that support: (a) Thick accents by agents apparently based in other countries--even supervisors--make their advice largely unintelligible. (b) Even when one can understand them, too many of the support personnel seem entirely clueless, taking the customer's time to no good end. Escalating to a supervisor sometimes works but often does not; and written support, usually provided as boilerplate, is usually still worse. (c) Inquiries to Amazon's sellers must almost always be made via Amazon's online form; and, incredibly, Amazon cannot track such inquiries or follow up unless the purchase has already been made. 2. Product descriptions. These are wrong much too often.  3. Product search. The variety of products available is overwhelming, and Amazon's product search engine is awful. For example, a search for a "queen-size single fitted sheet" yielded many hundreds of results (as I recall, about 1,400!), pointing to sheets of various sizes, nearly all sheets sets. Of all those results I found only 1 that matched my search criteria. One suspects that Amazon deliberately fudges search results to offer more choices, with the goal of increasing sales. 4. Merchant reviews. As of last check Amazon allows reviewers without significant limitation to withdraw their reviews. This policy encourages merchants -- many of whom depend on Amazon for patronage -- to go after reviewers whose reviews are not favorable in order to buy them off. This has happened to me. The consequence of these minuses is that you could easily spend hours trying to meet your need, which may in the end be unfulfilled or, even worse, fulfilled badly.

Twice now they have sold me used products as new. The last time, the cooking apparatus had old food residue on it. This situation is unhygienic. I am surprised the Food and Drug administration allows it.

I purchased an item 2 weeks ago, 9 days later the price goes down so I contacted them to request an adjustment, they refused. The only recourse I had was to unwrap the Christmas presents, repackage them and return them for a refund. Then I could repurchase the exact items at the lower price, less the shipping cost of returning them of course. They would also take 2-3 weeks to process the refund, tying up my $640 during the Christmas season. I've owned my Kindle fire for 4 years and use almost all of it's capabilities ..... including playing games ... most at level of 1000 or more. Somehow my Kindle got reset to factory level and I lost EVERYTHING .... customer service said to re-register the Kindle, requiring total setup ..... security, settings, etc. I'm still finding things to update. The games are gone ..... Amazon suggests I contact the game developers to get game data back. They have no idea how the Kindle got unregistered .... they don't have the capability to find out. BUT they did offer to compensate me for my inconvenience for hours of troubleshooting over the phone .... they offered to credit my account $10, which I declined. The net is that Amazon technical support is purely clerical ..... they have a script for  getting a customer running ..... at ground zero and that's all!!!! And they have no way for a customer to do their own backups ..... And they suggested I caused the problem ... even though it would have taken 4 steps for me to reset ..... and I would have ignored several warnings that data would be destroyed ..... I only signed on (no password problems) .... and was met with an empty system. Usually talking to a supervisor brings a new perspective .... but not with technical support ..... the answers were the same script .... clearly they have no technical skills ..... they did not even opening a problem. Only many, many apologies and a generous $10 compensation offer. I am left feeling it could happen again .... I wish I had chosen another brand device.

Amazon used to be my go-to place to save money and avoid going into shops (and pay for their rent!), but now there are so many different sellers and prices that you can no longer trust that you are getting a good deal. The same item can be priced *very* differently depending on the seller. Some prices are also absolutely ludicrous. For instance, I saw that someone was trying to sell the academic book that I authored for $1k !! It costs $100 directly from the publisher?! Shocking, to say the least. So although they have fantastic delivery and customer services, you constantly need to research whatever you wish to buy to make sure that you are not getting fooled. It's very tiring and time-consuming. There is absolutely no price regulation - you alone decide what you are willing to pay to get something delivered and/or rare. So prices don't match quality; rather, they reflect availability and the sheer greed of sellers. And they are killing our high street shops...

Their mobile website is almost impossible to use and their desktop site is not a whole lot better. Their customer service doesn't know what its own policies are and finding product information is almost impossible as customers who have no ability and/or interest in providing coherent input post on Amazon's "customer reviews" section of a product page and to make it more cumbersome, the reviews for all 400 of the 500 variations of Michael Jackson's THRILLER are grouped together with no easy way to tell many of them apart. More, even if you know EXACTLY which one you're looking for, you can type in its' barcode and still have to go through a multistep process to get to the item page you explicitly searched for. And the other 100 variations of Michael Jackson's THRILLER are just like stray cats with no way to distinguish between them except the ASIN which is nothing except a # that Amazon uses to identify the item in question when someone asks about it. Except most of these ASINs are for items that were long out of print before Amazon even existed and only exist because someone created an item page for it for who knows what reason, maybe to sell it on the Amazon Marketplace, and many of these ASINs go long abandoned.  Amazon remedies this tangled mess of a website by refunding your money no matter whose fault the issue is. It doesn't matter if the 3rd part seller screwed up, the post office or a gremlin. It's been refunded so all is well. Until next time.

So here - today I want to share a little bit of good news and common sense for all you online shoppers and people looking for that opportunity to get out of the mess you find yourselves in. We all struggle but it is when you are poor and needy and in debt that the pressures really hit home and where hopelessness tries to kill the joy of living. Everybody knows or want to know some kind of secret to making money and to be successful. A wise man listens to counsel but too many voices will drive you mad. Do you prefer the paperless route to getting rich quick, or do you have a proper plan to prosper that will make you rich? Countless money making offers and investment opportunities floats out there both online and offline. But for your own peace of mind and safety, it is most advisable to Google search different reviews on each selected choice before signing up or buying in. Many come with that deceitful free label that stings, like a hook to the bait. Often people are invited to financial seminars to help them cope or escape their current state of affairs into a Utopia, a lifestyle of milk and honey. And like any good business, they do require you to invest time and money. And as for good farming, it is essential to prepare the soil for sowing and reaping, which may take months and even years to fully mature. But dont despair, hard work has its rewards.  But it is in these hard times when the vulnerable and desperate are lured with fast food cash-ins and drive off scams. Most offers are so tempting it's hard to resist, and when swallowed it has that bittersweet ending. Just like, when the serpent deceived Eve with his cunning sales act. Did God really say that? Its because he doesn't want you to become like gods too. Just try it once, no one will know! And when she saw that the fruit was good to eat, she ate of the forbidden tree of knowledge of good and evil. Then she also gave to her husband, and when he took his first bite, the whole world went into a total Black-Out. And instead of becoming like gods, they got caught naked and hiding from God. This is a clip out of the book God and Money now available. It is a world of wisdom for one happy meal. But if you really can not afford it, I will send you the ebook for free.  https://www.amazon.com/God-Money-Andre-Cronje/dp/1985390019

Why does this company expect customers to answer questions about products?  Try to find how to reach customer service. Time yourself until you find a link. Except when it's not. There are so many exceptions. Amazon was my first online shopping experience and it was amazing. You placed your order and it arrived in a matter of days, it was exactly what you paid for w/o any worries. Then they started the Prime services , you pay $100.00 a year up front , get two day delivery, some Kindle book discounts and their TV shows . For me even though I probably spend close to a hundred in shipping , I don't want to be told to pay this amount and " you'll get better service from us !" So now if your not a Prime customer , your shipping can take days to weeks to arrive (if at all). Many times you deal with new seller's , and your order never comes. Amazon has purchased a newspaper , they've ventured into making movies , debating purchasing pharmaceutical and the one thing that got them started their losing focus on, great deals from reputable sellers and great shipping. If you stretch yourself to thin , you fall apart and their services are doing that. I ordered an item 4 times , from 4 different seller's , it took 2 months and it never came. Amazon did refund my money back through their A-Z customer service , but all I wanted was my item ! Now after all these years of being a dedicated customer , I'm looking for another place to shop.

Often I have seen that an items is advertised at a lower price than you end up paying and that is annoying. For example, you find a hat and the small size is cheap but the medium size is 2x the price of the small. There is not reason for such a price difference. Other times you see something for $4 and click on it only to find that the $4 is not an option at all and the cheapest color/size/etc is $6 for example soo.......find what you need and then still price compare.

Amazon is the easiest single source to shop from but all it takes is a single look at pricing history of an item to shock you. The price you pay is not consistent over time. Loved Amazon for many many years. Since Prime came along it became harder and harder as non-prime member to make purchases; to the point that I no longer make purchases from Amazon. I have reverted to using Ebay, Walmart Online, and alternate sites for products I want which Amazon will only sell as a prime product.This is the case with any new order now. Amazon has a lot to offer, that's for sure. However, I try not to order much that's either sold/shipped by Amazon or fulfilled by Amazon because they play too much with their shipping.  The last few orders I placed on Amazon that were either sold/fulfilled by Amazon took longer than a week just to get shipped. Most businesses can manage to ship out in-stock items in one business day, two tops. However, I've had Amazon wait 9 business days to ship, while my order's status has said "preparing for shipment" for 4 days. As I'm not Prime member, I feel like they do this on purpose so you'll have to wait upward of a week to get your items because they know that if they ship your items out the next business day, USPS will usually deliver in about 3 days, so why pay for Prime for a one day difference? I never have this issue when I order items sold by a third party. I've even called Amazon about why it was taking days to "prepare my shipment" but even they couldn't tell me why or even what the real status of my order was. Oddly enough, after first telling me that my order didn't go through due to a server issue to the items just not being in stock, about one hour later, my order shipped out from a city about 60 miles away from me. My order was delivered the next morning in a box that was way too big and not even taped all the way shut. Order from trusted third-party sellers. You'll have the best experience that way if you're not a Prime member.
Hate that it doesn't ship to all countries. Wanted to send a present straight to my friends and couldn't

When I finally received it in the mail ( around a month later ) it was nowhere near 1000 lumens. It was MAYBE around 50 lumens. We were both very disappointed considering I spent $20 on a flashlight I could buy at a gas station. The other problem is shipping. Amazon has the widest selection of goods in the world, and it usually has competitive prices. But a policy they appear to have implemented in the last year or so drags my rating well down. They seem to be trying to push people to pay for shipping (through either Prime or per-order paid shipping) by seriously degrading the free shipping. This is the way I normally order. Every order I have placed in the last year has not been shipped for at least 6 days, and usually more (my last order was 8 days ago, and it hasn't shipped yet), after I placed the order. The shipping itself is fast, always 1-2 days, so they aren't using a cheaper shipping method to save costs. But they hold your order for about a week before processing and shipping it so normally you will receive it 8-10 days after you place your order. Many other online outlets offer free shipping without this kind of delay (and some of them at about the same price for the merchandise). So Amazon is now a clearly inferior online shopping site with respect to free shipping.
They've sent me broken products & products that weren't mine because I didn't order said item. Wrong deliveries.

I was a huge amazon fan and spent a lot of money there as a prime member-its getting harder to contact a human when there is a problem, the do sell everything but you have to be careful because some of their "vendors" are pretty shady-one thing they do have is a great extended warranty company "fair trade" I highly recommend them-for many things you can do better elsewhere-their grocery delivery program is a total joke unless you are a rich rock star

I used to love Amazon. From 2006 to 2014 we were inseparable. Then, I started having issues. Prior to 2014, 99 % of my MANY orders came via UPS. I moved into town from the rural outskirts in 2014. My orders were then predominantly coming via United States Postal Service and therein was part of the reason I down rated them in this review. Orders are frequently delivered to wrong addresses, or not delivered at all. It has been a pain. I have begged Amazon to use UPS or FedEx for my orders. They refuse. Also, I started questioning the prices. I am not talking about the resellers, as they can price as absurdly as they wish. I mean items sold and shipped by Amazon: Dawn Dishwashing Liquid, 32.4 ounce is $3.99 in local and other online stores, but Amazon is asking $11.99 for the exact same thing. And that is just one of many examples I've found recently. I still love Amazon, but they are going to have to tighten up the ship as competition is growing. They must stop promising free shipping then charging me three times the market price. And they need to dump the USPS.

I think that they can open up to other locations around the globe as well. It would prove being an excellent opportunity because that would allow them to enhance their game. The competitive prices are attractive.
only slight problems with them occasionally. Usually will take care of it in a fairly quick manner though.

I'm a member of Prime and a routine shopper. Unfortunately, Amazon no longer has my back. The quality of goods is not consistent. They no longer back the consumer as they sell inferior products. Granted the price is low but poor quality means the consumer pays. It's important to be careful when you select.

Amazon is the place I primarily go for product reviews, then buy them elsewhere. Amazon never really seems to offer great deals unless you have Amazon Prime, in which case you would want to use it very regularly for it to become worth the yearly fee. Once in a while, I'll find something on Amazon that has a cheaper price than eBay or other random websites I find through Google Shopping, but probably 3 out of 4 times, I find that their prices are higher than the super discounted prices you can find on eBay, and are more on par with your local department stores. I also almost never find free shipping an option on Amazon, but you see it all the time on eBay. The only thing Amazon has going for them is the convenience factor of buying online, and of course a ton of product reviews to narrow down what you're looking for. Fortunately for me, I've been buying online well before Amazon became a big thing and I know of other places to grab good stuff for a fraction of the price.

If it werent for that ugly bald ceo id give it a good rating. he needs to stop degrading my president. hes a propagandist globalist with dteams of ruling the usa! most things are as ordered and i give bezo bozo no credit on that!

I've ordered a lot from Amazon over the years, used to love them, but policies have changed. Maybe just too big and don't know how to manage it. Just yesterday I had an order from a vendor needed to be canceled. The vendor sent an email that said no problem, I'd bought from them before. At the same time received one from Amazon saying it was shipped. On Sunday? Still have not received an answer to correct status. The main issue with Amazon though is their free shipping. You have to buy so much to qualify, an amount they raise at times. Yet if you take advantage of this your order goes to the back of the line. Not always do they meet the promised shipping date if it takes too long, they just change it. This has happened every time it seems like. It's taken up to a week before for an item to ship out when choosing free shipping, but if you use a debit card they bill you when an order placed, not when shipped as most vendors do. Vendors have an authorization when placing an order so payment guaranteed until shipped, then hard charge, but Amazon actually runs it through now when order placed. Maybe they know it may take a week to ship. They've actually acknowledged using free shipping makes it a low priority order. Only if a private vendor ships themselves does it go out faster.They're CS is apparently outsourced which at times makes it hard to communicate. Just not the same Amazon it once was.
Amazon is great but when shipping something back for a refund some times they do 3-5 different refunds amount for one transaction it's very hard to keep track and sometimes refund don't even show up

I like the prices, but unless if your using prime orders take too long to arrive. I had some items come in that were incorrect, but was able to send back free of charge and was refunded the money as soon as UPS scanned the return barcode.

I bought an electronic device off a seller on Amazon. They had very little experience on Amazon but the price was right so I ordered a device. It was charged to my credit card immediately and shipped to New York instead of Texas where I live. Tracking in Amazon showed delivered to Texas. Tracking in UPS showed New York. Something very fishy about it because seller refused to respond to emails. It took almost 3 weeks to get my refund on my credit card. I told Amazon that this was fraud, but they seemed very unconcerned at first. I should not had to go to as much effort as I did to get my money back.

Two companies to beware of: I purchased a product through EBAY from Hommee-fashion501 and decided to cancel within 10 to 15 minutes but the company refused to cancel the order. Ebay said they would refund my money but I have not seen the refund yet or the product. The second company is Canserin through Amazon. The product received is defective and it took about 5 weeks to deliver, but the company wants me to send photos of the product and the package it came in before sending a replacement. And I would have to wait another 5 weeks.  I no longer have the option of sending pictures since uploading Safari on my Mac. I contacted Amazon but all they can/will do is send an email to the company. I believe both products are from China but Hommee-fashion501 has a California location. Not sure about Canserin's location. I will no longer purchase anything from China or from either of these companies.

I have requested once that amazon remove me from the email sharing- pool that sends your email to third party sellers who in turn spam your inbox with "How did we do? Do you like our product? Please leave us a positive review!" I actually responded once to one of the emails, the product was supposedly delivered on a Sunday but I did not recieve it. Then I got an email back from the third party seller stating that amazon was responsible for shipping and I would need to contact amazon about a lost product. This company just wanted a positive review for a missing purchase. If amazon is responsible for selling, acquring, and shipping the item to me, why does this third party company need my email? If I so choose to leave a review, that is my business. If Macy's foreign suppliers called you every time you left the store to ask you to go online and review the clothes you just bought, would you shop at Macy's? This should not be allowed, amazon.

I bought a shirt that said it was sold by amazon, not third party, but it was clearly a forgery. The image provided on the website showed the picture on the shirt taking up most of the shirt, but the shirt I got had a picture about the size of a standard sheet of notebook paper, AND it was badly smeared! I also bought some makeup from a brand I usually buy at the mall, and it was crumbly and hard, and it smelled weird. What's frustrating is that even after contacting Amazon about these scammers, Amazon continues to let them sell their bogus products!

Over 10 years I have probably spent $10,000 on Amazon, especially given the photo equipment I have purchased. They still provide fair value and a decent customer experience BUT now (I) non-prime delivery times are intentionally delayed; (Ii) the minimum purchase required for free delivery is up; and (III) pricing is no longer reliably competitive. For many items, Jet.com provides a better experience - on all of cost, minimum purchase for free delivery and speed of delivery (in NYC, often next day.). The selection is way narrower but it offers a significantly better experience if they carry what you want. It seems evident that these policies are designed to push customers to subscribe to Amazon Prime. That is fair as a business model, but it may not be fair as a competitive model.

Amazon customer service is good. They have generally refunded, replaced and apologised in a timely way when required. The reason I look elsewhere before buying from them is the way they treat their employees. We have all seen news items about conditions in their fulfillment centres, many of us know a self-employed driver who has been driven mad and had to throw in the towel. Some of us have seen their employment contracts, or the contracts their chosen temp agencies impose. Basically, if you're a potential customer they love and respect you, but if you're a worker they exploit you. Now, a bit of a dogleg here admittedly, but it occurred to me that they sell lots of music, film, books etc.. The creative souls who make this stuff can get famous, they can get knighted, they can work in TV, radio, the media, they win awards AND THEY OFTEN HAVE LIFE STYLES THAT INCLUDE LOTS OF BOOZE AND DRUGS, but if you wanna work for them and you've had a happy fag in the last six months you can get lost. Hypocrisy. And horrible hubris. Look somewhere else first. Just USE Amazon like they USE people.

I shop at Amazon.com because it has such a variety of choices of products. However, that same variety means that they deal with a large number of venders, and follow-up on damaged or missing packages is almost non-existent. Sometimes the person responsible for delivery puts the package in the mailbox (which is against the law). That means I have to get to the mailbox before the postman does. If the postman sees the package in the mailbox before I do, the package is confiscated and I have to pay postage on it - again! I have tried several ways of trying to contact Amazon.com about this problem and have been ignored. The one time they did respond, they told me the company supplying the product had gone out of business and they could not do anything to help me.

I mainly just publish comic strip books for free with them now. Although you can generate 70 % of what you charge for your books in sales by choosing the 70-percent option for the $2.99-$9.99 range, overall sales have plummeted for me here the last four years plus they don't provide your views tally; consequently, I had to move most of my books to another market. On the bright side, you can possibly get a $1500 advance by using their Kindle Scout program as a member; however, your submission must have at least 50,000 words and fall into a certain category. Minus getting a sale, you will generate revenue for each page of one of your books that someone reads on their Kindle but it is usually pennies literally. I give them strong credit for publishing your submission within 12 hours.

but customer service is not so ideal. You are basically on your own. You don't know where some of the stuff comes from. One order took almost 3 months to arrive .. found out they had to ship it all the way from china

Since Amazon attempts to be a one-stop shop, you don't always get the best. Third party vendors make it more difficult to shop for or return items because each seller has different policies regarding shipping. It's not all upfront, and the appearance of the Amazon site doesn't change when you pick items from vendors versus Amazon. Like there's no signal that says, "Hey, you're buying from Amazon, you're buying from BooksAhoy, CrapShoesAlabama, and ConnorY1983. Is that ok? They will charge you for shipping, they will charge you to return the items you buy, and these guys ARE NOT fulfilled by Amazon." Also, Amazon desperately wants you to be a Prime Member, raising the cost of free shipping from $25 to $35 to $49. Now, that doesn't include books, either. You have to spend $25 on books alone to get free shipping on books. And still find stuff adding to $49 to get free shipping on the entire order, that is if you don't have Prime. It's just not customer-friendly anymore.

Amazon, like Google and Adobe, is trying to take over your lifestyle by moving you from a buyer to a subscriber. They are attempting to get you hooked on a regular basis so that they, I assume, can grow their companies into power house players by setting a core customer base and by having direct access to your money supply. Amazon was an excellent company, but today it's personality has changed from helping us to simply a company of self-greed. Watch out what you buy and more importantly how you are engineered to buy from Amazon. Also, don't try to communicated with them. They don't want to hear from you. If you do break through that maze and get a note to them, the response will come from India or Pakistan and not be directed at your actual question. The company is now facing competition from a few others like jet.com. But each of these has not equaled the power of the amazon Web site. When they do,they might prove to be a bit better than Amazon. But Amazon right now, owns the world and is behaving as though they own us along with it.

I use Amazon a lot - the prices are usually great and sometimes exceptional. But when it screws up it is a nightmare.  I wrote an entire blog post about one experience. http://yasashiikuma.com/2016/05/score-u-haul-1-amazon-0/ Three months later I have never heard back from them.

Amazon Prime used to ship via UPS. When the switched to using USPS, they made a big mistake in meeting the needs of their customers. I purchase ALOT from Amazon. Their prices can be good (not always) but for me it saves time and it's convenient. Or at least it used to be. I live in a rural town in a heavily populated county. USPS delivers mail to mailboxes on the street, not door to door. Even with a large mailbox, packages don't fit. The 2 day shipping turns to 5 days because I have to travel to the Post Officeto pick up packages. It's an easy 20 minutes each way to pick up packages between 9-5:00 ( if there is no commute traffic to deal with.). That doesn't work when a person is employed. UPS delivers to my door, but not USPS. My Prime membership comes with other perks; such as free movie streaming. I can't use any of the other perks because of having Satelite Internet and data limits. I'll continue to use Amazon because of the size of their selections and and the ease of ordering. I hate that they use USPS and if there was a better alternative to Amazon, I'd take it.

I love their website, prices and selection. I can find things on Amazon that are not available anywhere else. I hate that because I am not a "Prime" member they process my orders very slowly. Amazon.com prices are going up and up... Why? I've been shopping on Amazon.com for more than a decade now. However, in the last couple of years, their prices have been surging up well above the manufacturer's suggested retail price (MSRP) on many items. It used to be that they had the lowest prices on most anything. Now, that is not the case and I am very leery when I shop on Amazon.com  Just this week, I walked through retail shops like Bed, Bath and Beyond, (certainly not a bargain store) and checked prices on Amazons site on my smartphone while in the shop. I found BBBs prices (before discount) were significantly lower (40% lower on some items) than Amazon's best "prime members only" prices. Yes, Amazon's price was nearly double the price of some items at BBB. Every item I looked at was priced lower than the best Amazon.com's price from any seller thereon. And again, that is before factoring in a 20% added discount at BBB.  When I go to some manufacturer's websites, I find their MSRP is significantly lower than Amazon's best prices. For example, just today I found the Navy Sport-Brella Versa-Bella priced at $26 on Amazon.com when it can be purchased directly from the manufacturer for $20. That same umbrella is available at many other retail stores and websites for the same $20, but Amazon.com wants an extra 30% above MSRP. Why??? And now with Amazon's $49 minimum for free shipping, I am looking at other options and away from their greed-driven ways. I understood when it went from $25 to $35 (times change; shipping costs go up). But then it jumped to $49 in no time. While other companies are lowering their minimum purchase for free shipping, Amazon is raising theirs.  Frankly, with Amazon.com's jacked-up prices, it's getting harder and harder to find $50 worth of items that I want on their website that I can't get elsewhere for less money. What happened, and why such a significant greed-driven shift in the last year or two, Amazon? How much profit is really enough, Mr. Bezos??? My suggestion to other shoppers: Do what Im now doing Check and compare prices in local retail shops and/or on other websites before you buy from Amazon.com. While Amazons prices are still better on some items, their prices on other items may give you severe sticker shock. In the end you may be surprised to learn that Amazon.com is not the bargain store it used to be.

I PURCHASED AN ITEM FOR MY DAUGHTER'S BIRTHDAY: THE WEBSITE SHOWED: Guaranteed delivery date: Sept. 29, 2016 If you order in the next 17 hours and 33 minutes (Details)  Items shipped from Amazon.com  Char-Broil TRU-Infrared Patio Bistro Electric Grill, Graphite $139.59 FREE Shipping for Prime members Sold by:Amazon.com LLC  Choose your Prime delivery option: Thursday, Sept. 29  FREE Standard Shipping  In Stock. Want it Thursday, Sept. 29? Order within 17 hrs 32 mins and choose Standard Shipping at checkout. Details  MY MAIN PROBLEM WAS THAT, ONCE I ACTUALLY ORDERED THE ITEM, IT THEN SHOWED THAT THE ITEM WOULD NOT BE DELIVERED UNTIL FRIDAY, SEPT 30 ..!! I CALLED AMAZON AND SPOKE TO 4 DIFFERENT PEOPLE IN CUSTOMER SERVICE. EACH ONE TOLD ME THAT THIS DID NOT MAKE SENSE TO THEM EITHER BUT THAT THEY WERE UNABLE TO UPGRADE THE DELIVERY OR SPEED THE DELIVERY IN ANY WAY AND MY ITEM WOULD STILL NOT BE DELIVERED UNTIL SEPT. 30 - EVEN THOUGH THE WEBSITE SHOWS "GUARANTEED DELIVERY DATE OF SEPT 29" NONE OF THE 4 PEOPLE COULD EXPLAIN WHAT THE WORD "GUARANTEED" MEANT IN THIS INSTANCE, NOR WOULD ANY OF THEM OFFER ANY SORT OF COMPENSATION FOR THIS 'FALSE ADVERTISING' ..  ONE REP TOLD ME THAT IF MY DAUGHTER HAD ORDERED IT DIRECTLY THEN SHE MIGHT HAVE RECEIVED IT BY 09-29 .. AND THAT IF I HAD ORDERED IT FOR MYSELF, I MIGHT HAVE RECEIVED IT BY 09-29 .. THIS DID NOT MAKE ANY SORT OF SENSE TO ME WHATSOEVER .. ?! THE LAST REP (SUPPOSEDLY SOME SORT OF SUPERVISOR) TOLD ME THAT EVEN THOUGH THE WORDING SAID "GUARANTEED DELIVERY DATE ... ... " SUDDENLY HER WEBSITE SHOWED THAT THE EARLIEST DELIVERY DATE WAS NOW 09-30 .. EVEN THOUGH I WAS LOOKING DIRECTLY AT THE WEBSITE AT THAT MOMENT AND MY SCREEN STILL SHOWED 09-29 .. ?!?!? I ASKED HER FOR AN UPPER ESTABLISHMENT PERSON TO DISCUSS THIS MATTER WITH AND SHE TOLD ME THAT CUSTOMER SERVICE WAS THE ONLY PLACE I COULD TALK TO TO AT ALL ..  IT IS QUITE APPARENT THAT THIS PROBLEM WILL NEVER BE RESOLVED OR CORRECTED AND THAT CUSTOMERS CANNOT TRUST THE AMAZON WEBSITE TO BE CORRECT .. THIS IS QUITE DISTURBING, AS I HAVE BEEN A REGULAR CUSTOMER OF AMAZON FOR YEARS.. AT THIS POINT, I AM BEYOND FRUSTRATED ..

My biggest issue with Amazon is the reviews.  The have paid reviewers at the top of the lists. Don't see a conflict with someone being paid to review a product?  They lump all reviews for similar models, some models are vastly different in specs and configuration. You could have one model that is great and another model that is a POS but Amazon lumps them together and you don't know until someone posts a model number in their review. You will think a item is great when it is known to be defective. Amazon is well aware of this issue but will not do anything about it. Don't ever use Amazon Services. First off, Amazon techs are subcontractors, nothing more. We have never set foot in a Amazon facility. Amazon does not actually vet their technicians. They have changed policies so many times due to techs going onsite drunk/high and stealing/breaking things at customers sites. I don't doubt that Amazon fixes all the issues but some items are not replaceable. Issues with businesses quoting one price then jacking it up when they get onsite. Amazon returns are great, Customer service is great IF YOU USE THE PHONE. Email support is terrible, just like everyone else. Cut and paste responses that have no bearing on your issue.

To be fair to Amazon, books are great through this source. I got some great editions of Kant and Sartre through this site. However, fellow movie collectors: beware. I have coveted Raise The Red Lantern for ages. Try getting it from the two mail order movie sites like MU. Amazon promised me a pristine new copy for a king's ransom, I paid close to fifty bucks for a single movie, I know, stop laughing, when it arrived it looked like a whole drawer's worth of silverware had fallen on it. The circular scratches covered it completely, I never play the return game, in Amazon's defense, perhaps they would have corrected it. Unfortunately and, conveniently coincidentally, it just happened to be the last 'new' one they had. Now you see why I didn't try, don't you?   If this was the 'brand new' one, imagine what the 'used' ones looked like? I have had three orders of philosophical works that were all excellent. I simply need to share with fellow movie collectors that this was the single worst looking fifty dollar 'brand new' disc that I have ever seen. Three players would not play this movie, I would stick to other items besides DVDs. In Amazon's defense, both mail order movie houses are notorious for sending other people's returns out as new movies. I dropped one of them for consistently mailing me unplayable, scratched beyond repair discs. I did take offense at the adjectives 'brand new' 'never been played,' this disc looked worse than movies I have owned for over a decade. Stick To Other Items. Take Care. Deus Vobiscum. Q.E.D.

Anybody who believes that Amazon doesn't have counterfeit vendors are in for a shock. THEY DO!!! I have read about Amazon's counterfeit problem but didn't want to believe it existed. I do now that I have purchased counterfeit cosmetics and a Isaac Mizrahi bag. Back in March I purchased what I thought was an Isaac Mizrahi bag. I was saving it for the summer. I received it and thought it looked nice but didn't thoroughly examine it. When I finally looked at the bag...Isaac Mizrahi does not stamp his bag in cheap gold ink. The bag wasn't even leather. By the time it was uncovered...it was too late to get refunded. I also have bought counterfeit lipsticks. I did 2 things. I went to YouTube on how to spot the fakes and it all matched up. I had a family friend who is a manager at an Ulta cosmetics store confirm this too. I would not have suspected an inexpensive makeup brand like NYX to have counterfeits buy unfortunately they do. I was refunded but that's not the point. I was going to order an Anastasia Beverly Hills contour palette at $45 ...$5 more than they charge at Sephora. I read at least 5 reviews that said they received a counterfeit and one person uploaded a photo of the color swatches of the real vs the fake. They are charging $5 more for a counterfeit item. Amazon has some good deals and some things are overpriced. I will still order from them but am limited to what I buy from there after reading the counterfeit reviews and experiencing this with some of their items myself.

I buy via Amazon about 3 times a month...I find them very good to compare similar products of what you are looking for, and narrow down a buying decision. I stay away from items that have a high chance of needing to be returned, so I do my research first to avoid the return-process. I also try to stick to products that Amazon themselves ships, so I have more predictability on how long it will take. Up to now, have only returned one item out of many purchased...good track record for Amazon...return-process was smooth, but rather avoid it.. One of my few complaints about this site, is that many products are not displayed-photographed properly nor extensively, so often it's hard to see as much as I want to see; the whole idea of buying online is to be able to visualize what we are buying as best as possible, since we are not at a store actually seeing-feeling the product. Amazon could make the website more visually appealing and have their vendors improve the product representation in photos. Another minor issue, is that the first thing I want to see from a vendor, other than feedback, is where do they ship from?( When not shipped from Amazon)...Amazon gives you the info, but not to handy (you have to dig for it). Conclusion: I usually use Amazon for specific products that I've pre-decided I need and know something about (usually I check Ebay as well to compare)...I don't wander around just looking at products for shopping-fun, but rather chase specific product-needs I have determined (example: I need a spare camera battery for my Nikon: I go to Amazon first, and cross-check with Ebay prices. Eight out of 10 times I find Amazon offers better choices & service, and a simpler return-process if needed... Example of an Amazon typical purchase of mine: camera lens...Best Buy has it at store for significantly more than Amazon...Ebay has a similar price but a vendor with feedback I don't care for...Amazon has it at a competitive price, and shipped-handled by Amazon: I buy it from Amazon. Good site if you know what you want.

Dear Amazon, You've changed. I miss who you used to be when you were young and insecure with your place in this world. Back when you refused to chase after others, but preferred to "innovate ahead" of them. We all got so used to your prices being the lowest, back when you'd undercut everyone, even to the detriment of your own balance sheets. You were such a risk-taker. But you've long secured your place at the top of the e-commerce food chain, and your price points are creeping steadily upward as you continue to eat yourself. You're finding new ways to manipulate us into spending more in order to get free 2-day shipping. You've rolled out highly complex subscription programs that confuse and befuddle. You're trying to be Saks and Google and Apple and Netflix, etc. all at once. But you've never been that cool, nor will you be.  I'll never buy your fancy clothes, nor your failed smart phone (although if the price drops any further, I might pick one up as a toy for my 5-year-old nephew). But I will admit, with impunity, you're the first place I go when I know exactly what I need and I need it within 2 days. Sorry for using you for your cheap and fast shipping. Sorry if I've reduced you to a booty call. Hope we can still see each other when it's right for both of us.  XOXO, jc

I purchased Amazon Prime earlier this year for their guaranteed 3 day shipping. One of the items I purchased was lost in transit, this was told to me by the customer support gentleman I first spoke with. This gentleman also offered to refund me the original purchase and send me the same item (if i agreed to buy it again) with 1 day shipping. After being placed on hold for 20 minutes while the finalized the 2nd order I am told that 1 day shipping is not available for this item, and amazon is able to offer me a 5$ gift certificate for the hassle. I was already a little bothered that after 8 days I had to call for Amazon to tell me the package was lost. To then be offered a quick fix and then be told its not possible, brought me to a point of anger. Amazon needs to train their customer support team to better handle situations and use better wording when speaking to guests. As someone who works directly with clients, one of the basic rules in customer care is to NEVER offer something you cannot guarantee and that is exactly what happened. The manager/supervisors solution was to extend my Prime membership an extra month. Besides this one incident, Amazon has been able to deliver items within 3 days of purchase including Sundays. It's a good company and has its benefits as an frequent online shopper. I would suggest the customer service department receive extra training.
Amazon is as evil as any other huge American corporation, but when it comes to hard-to-find items at decent prices, it can't be beat. Their customer support is cumbersome, but at least it exists.

I've had this card for 14 months and haven't encountered any issues. I'm a die-hard Amazon shopper, so I thought with 3 points for Amazon.com purchases, this is the card for me. Then I learned... The 3 points only applies to Amazon.com purchases (plus a few other categories on Amazon.com, see below). Because so much of the merchandise on Amazon's site is not from "Amazon.com", but from affiliated and third party sellers, you may find that many of your purchases made on Amazon.com aren't really "Amazon.com" and therefore don't actually qualify for the 3 points. For instance, if you see items sold by Amazon Marketplace (which is common), beware, you'll just receive 1 point per dollar spent. I was so disappointed because the fine print (pasted below) isn't explicit about this, so I feel a little misled.

UPDATE, 2/27/16:  Recently Amazon raised their minimum free shipping price from $35 to $49. Apparently it's a move to promote their $99/year Prime service, which I used on a free month's trial basis and did not like. They are going to lose a lot of business from me. $35 is reasonable if you want to buy one or two items, but I don't spend $49 every time I go shopping.  Adios, Amazon. _______________________________________________ MY ORIGINAL REVIEW, EDITED: Amazon's merchandise is packaged well and shipped quickly, with very few exceptions. If you have a problem, they work with you. Their customer service and return policy are superior.  Use caution when purchasing food products. Consider the time of year, the vendor's reviews, and customer reviews. You may not always be able to return edible items, but in one case I did get a refund because the product was completely disgusting. Be polite and thorough in your reasons for returning anything, and there's often a chance Amazon will refund your money.

I really like Amazon but I purchased a tablet based on the reviews. Boy was that a mistake. I bought a 10" Tablet and it was terrible. How could this be with so many great reviews? I went back and noticed that the reviews for 3 tablets were joined together. I could only find 2 reviews of 177 that were for the 10", most were for the 7" and a few for the 8". So I started looking at other items only to find there were 100s of examples just like this one. That this is the way Amazon does it. SO DO NOT buy a product based on the reviews summary. You need to read every review to find the ones for the product you are considering.

Amazon may be a great place to buy as a prime member, but the message boards are really poor to discuss in. With the "Do you think this post adds to the discussion" feature makes it an useless system wherever you go. It is the only system for their forums, but some kids had to abuse it just to make a fool out of themselves. Most forums don't have that feature. Other than that, I was thinking of getting a fighting pad controller for the PS3. However, they ran out and it costs more than $35 to get it from... United Kingdom. Some prices of the products the other sellers handed out are more than their original prices. It's unbelievable to have Gears of War on the PC being sold secondhand for $33 on Amazon compared to $20 on Windows Games Live Marketplace. What's good for me is the prime membership. They may give me free shipping, but I'm still furious with the warehouse deals selling a game "like new" for $33. Seriously, Jeff Bezos sold me the Kindle Fire, then trying to sell people with the HD version and now he wants to compete against Apple for a Kindle smartphone? He makes me laugh to ever think of going against the big two of the computer industry. They don't have a lot apps, but I'm sure they're a waste. I'm giving it a 3/5. The prime membership may be strong, but the customer services mentioned by others along with the buyers/sellers community are weak. I suggest not go to the discussion boards.

To date I haven't had a problem returning an Amazon product within the return window and sometimes I've been giving extended time to do so. But to my surprise I've bought a few bad items based on FAKE 5 or 4 star reviews. Some of those reviews stick out easly due to them having the same typo error patterns. Example: "love this.great product." Or "bought two.love it." I have also noticed "Bad" reviews that were fake. They sometimes name another product they say is better. Some are being done by competiting companies and about 95% are not from Verified Buyers. Within the comment section under a bad review is where I first noticed a FAKE bad review. The sellers would be trying to resolve the issue and the customer seem to not want any type of resolution not even in returning the product. The seller claimed that the buyer was not a real buyer and that it was a fake review and all the customer had to do is return the product but they have no product to return. I'm sure the ones I've read like this we're fake.  My advise is to make sure the reviews are Verified reviews. I don't trust all of those either but this is a good place to start. Read and ask plenty of questions in the Q&A. Read through the good and bad reviews. Check comments to see if the seller responded to any of the bad reviews

Amazon. The go to shopping site for all things. Amazon is very convenient and you can find practically anything you want for sale there. In addition, you usually can find it at a reasonable price. They did comp me extra months of Prime when I complained, however. In addition there are many perks-from free movies to books(available for a kindle reader or smartphone app) to music. When all is said and done, Amazon seems to be the way of the world now!

I am not a speed reader, but I do read a lot of books. I get content for my Kindle app from several different places, including Amazon.com. Content (as long as it is in a format used by the Kindle app) can be sent to Amazon.com and registered in their cloud storage for free. I've been a member of Amazon since 2012 and have sent over 2,500 different .mobi, .pdf and.epub files to be stored in the Kindle cloud. Unfortunately, today I found out that Amazon/Kindle can't find much of the content I've sent/registered with them. Amazon insists all my content is still registered and available but can only find 357 different files. (This "lost" content is the reason Amazon.com doesn't get 5 stars from me.)

Shipping can be pricey, but orders are handled very efficiently - provided there are no requests attached. Amazon does not respond to special requests, like delayed shipping - you place the order, payment is approved, and the goods are on the way. Customer service can be time-consuming, as you do not deal with a single person, if you need to make multiple contacts. overall, a good organisation to deal with when you are up to play with the system.

90% of the time, I am completely satisfied with Amazon. The most common issue I have is shipping, I've ordered things with free 2 day shipping that have always arrived when expected, but other things I've ordered with standard shipping, seem to sit in a warehouse somewhere until shipping time estimate arrives, causing late arrival more often than pleases me. I believe they do this to try to incentivise customers into joining Prime or paying higher rates for shipping priority. I've handled shipping and receiving duties during my career and sales that would have gone to Amazon lately, have gone elsewhere that handle S/H more the way I always did.  For a positive note, I only have received one order, in the several years I've been a customer, that didn't meet my expectations due to a missing part, but the cost of getting it on my own was less than the hassle of dealing with Amazon on the issue.

I had the wonderful opportunity to join Amazon this year. My husband and I wanted to change one of our viewing services to something different to get more of the variety we were hoping for. Im so happy we did. The shows and viewing options are awesome, but they are just the tip of the iceberg. Free 2 day shipping has saved us so many times when we needed something very fast. Weve discovered if you can wait just a few days more, usually Amazon will give you a small credit toward one category or another and they can add up and allow you to get some fun things. I keep hearing people describe the features Amazon had before I joined and I really feel like I missed out on some very fun options like being able to get a large variety free books to read every month. I love what Im seeing but I havent heard anything about new features that were comparable to what was taken away. Its unusual to see a company cut back on what they offer instead of adding to it or changing it to something comparable. Still, this is the Amazon I know, and although the removed features sound like they could make it even greater, I still enjoy what they do offer. I suppose ignorance is bliss as long as they hold off on removing features Im getting used to having with them.

The return process is exceptional. All you have to do is locate the order on your account, hit return items and they send you a return label which you can just print off through your email. Then you stick it on there and ship it back no hassle. They also give you plenty of time to send your items back out. Instead of the normal 2-3 business days most places give you. You don't have to talk to a customer service rep at all and you don't have to send out emails and wait for a response. You also do not have to wait for your refund; as soon as you drop your return off at the ups or local post office and they scan it in, you get your full refund.  The customer service if you do decided to call is complicated and they mess up your orders hard core if you need something changed. I placed 2 orders and needed to cancel one so I called the phone line and asked them to cancel it. They cancelled the wrong one so I had to call back again and cancel everything because the rep was confused and didn't know what he was doing.Then It was a fight and alot of confusion about the refund for the orders. I guess it all worked out in the end but I didn't re order the purchase I had originally wanted to keep. Instead of cancelling an order it is easier to have it sen to you and do process a refund. It is much easier. They also have a lot of fake reviews on items but they are pretty easy to spot.  Other than that I use amazon for alot. Love it.

However I've also had packages that did not arrive by the schedualed date and they gave me a full refund no questions asked. So like i said it's pretty good though it does have its annoyances. Keep in mind that I do still shop here regularly so the good does outway the bad a majority of the time. It is my go to site for anything I need when I dont want to pay full price.

It advised me to only do so if I was satisfied, otherwise to respond directly to them. I emailed customer service at Amazon asking if this was condoned and/or prevalent and what action they would take. Try emailing customer services at Amazon. You can simply cannot. There is a lengthy procedure but no options for general points like this So.. two things. Their reviews from 3rd parties may be highly biased and when you try to be ever so helpful by forwarding a copy of the 3rd party's email to Amazon, you cannot do so and have to resort to this. Maybe Amazon will read it. And, think of an opinion poll on whether Americans approve of Trump, asking them only to respond if they are satisfied. It really is terrible.
