I have bought DVDs and books from Amazon for many years. Ordering and delivery updates impeccable. Never any uncertainty. And they could turn up sources for out-of-print books and rather obscure foreign-language DVDs. But lately I have run into dead-ends on some items, particularly on the number of outside suppliers from which to choose the best version of a title. They are often forgetting to mention if an English language DVD has subtitles (required to follow some plots and nerdy dialogues). It's just a bit harder to collect the vital statistics for a prospective purchase regarding publication data, abridgement, photos, translators. The things which make one edition of a book better than another. I could approach suppliers for the details but in the past I could usually get them from the Amazon descriptive entry or sometimes by looking at the book cover thumbnail. Views of other viewers and readers welcome.

I don't find the website that easy to use when you are looking for something specific and trying to figure out who to buy from. Ebay is much easier to know who the seller is and be able to check them out and communicate with them before buying. Amazon is mostly just find it and buy it - it takes a lot of tracking to ask about an item or check into the seller if you can even figure out who the seller is. I like to just buy directly from Amazon and I only buy products I am already familiar with so I know what to expect. Amazon return is easy but if you return for anything other than broken product, you will have to pay the return shipping so it isn't a place you want to try new products out like pet food or buy clothes you aren't sure the size of for that manufacturer unless you don't care about paying to return something. Unless you are prime which I wouldn't know about, shipping can take a long time for certain things. I've had to wait a few days even before my item shipped, as though Amazon was trying to order it to sell to me after I bought it, but they tell you right up front it will be a few days before it ships & then when it does ship, it gets to you fast. The prices are high. I find a lot of things cheaper elsewhere but if you only like to shop in the same place and don't have time to shop around for better prices - you can pretty much find what you want in Amazon as long as it is still manufactured and sold. Otherwise you have to rely on Ebay for hard to find or out of production items & hope someone is selling theirs or stocked up and has some to spare. The thing I use Amazon for the most is product reviews. Whether I am buying from Amazon or not , I never make a big purchase and sometimes don't make a small purchase without first seeing if their are any Amazon reviews. I figure some of them are fakes and self serving but trust the majority of them because you have to have an Amazon account to review & they also show the verified purchasers. Anyhow whether you like or not its a massive online force that isn't going anywhere.
I love how I can find anything I need on Amazon! Better yet, I can find everything for a better price than in our local stores.

Some of my best experiences have been with amazon.com!! I love the fact that as I established myself with this online business I started getting my return refunds to me the same day I shipped a return back!! Even when I first started returning items it would only take about a full budiness week before my refund showed up on my account which wasn't too bad either! I've gotten Great Deals On various things that have really made my life easier. I love the fact that I have access to bulk items on almost anything!! Now I've become addicted to comparison shopping in the stores like Wal-Mart, Whole Foods, Ulta, etc for my beauty supplies essential oils. I go on to amazon.com and see if I can get it for better price and oftentimes I can!! especially when it comes to hard-to-find items like essential oils,shipping boxes ,shipping supplies, certain discontinued fragrances/ perfumes, cosmetics , etc. these items are almost always cheaper on Amazon! I love that the return procedure is easy too. I can drop off my returns at my local Staples that has a UPS drop off on site. I love the fact that even though I refuse to pay for Prime which is $99 a year they still have thousands of items that offer free shipping with a minimum purchase so if there are several items I plan on buying and they all offer free shipping with a minimum I usually end up getting free shipping anyway so for me it's always great!! Sometimes I wait until I need a couple of things that allows me to meet the minimum and then I get free shipping without spending $99 a year which I'm sure pays for itself in the long run for consistent. but I'm one of those people that just never knows when I'm going to be shopping on Amazon! sometimes I shop every 3 months sometimes I find something i love every month and sometimes I can go 6 months without making a purchase !! especially if I buy a lot at one time I might only shop 3-4 times a year so on average paying $33 for free shipping kind of doesn't work out for me BUT if you're someone who constantly shops then the $99 is probably worth it!  the only criticism I have of Amazon is that I wish they would get rid of those overseas Chinese based businesses that sell clothing that are so far off the u.s. sizing that every other review i read is negative about buyes ending up having to return the item because it fit horribly or was made from super cheap material.  Often times the return cost was so much it paid to just keep the item !! which is very disappointing so I always have to check to see if the sizing is US or a Chinese conversion chart because that right away is a red flag for me! If they got rid of those sellers I think it help. They don't need subpar cheap items being sold through their site you can only hurt them in the long run bc I've heard plenty of people who were thinking they were getting this amazing bargain and great fashion ended up with this super cheap stuff plus arriving from overseas sometimes takes weeks!! and when the item finally arrives and it's two and three sizes too small. I've only bought one item that I knew was not from a us-based manufacturer. I decided to take a chance because I had been looking for this item and of course when I got it not only was it super small but it was defective because there was no button hole for the button!!!which was hilarious and proof positive to me that I need to stay away from those companies! but other than that great experience every time

Amazon is a great place to get what you need at a great price. Their customer service is great. You can get products that you need at great prices and Amazon stands behind everything they sell. However, like eBay, Amazon is notorious for scalpers who buy products and then resale them for hundreds over MSRP due to shortage of these items. Apple products and Nintendo products come to mind... If you want something, be sure to purchase them from legitimate sellers. Don't fall for scalpers which Amazon should not allow. That is the reason I deduct a point from this review. Scalpers are the reason why we can't buy products at the MSRP prices... they buy up the supply dry and resale them for much higher prices. If Amazon and eBay don't allow these scalpers to do business on their sites, consumers would still have a chance to buy these at fair prices.

I've been an Amazon Prime member for years, and up until recently I've been 100% satisfied with it. Recently, Amazon has started using something called "Share Post" for their shipments and it sucks. They ship UPS to the local Post Office and drop the shipments so the post office will be responsible for the remainder of the delivery. I guess it's cheaper, but I recently had 5 different shipments get lost in that process. For people who live on rural routes, you can't use the street address which is required by UPS; instead you have to list the PO box because the post office doesn't do home delivery in certain areas. It wouldn't be such a big deal if, during the ordering process, there was a disclaimer notifying the buyer which form of delivery was being used. That way the proper address (street or PO Box) could be listed and there wouldn't be this confusion.

Pros 1) Amazon Prime offers free 2-day shipping for many products. 2) Amazon Prime offers some free music and movies. 3) Amazon Prime offers free returns for some items and the return methods are hasslefree. Did you notice something? Yeah, Amazon rocks when you have Prime membership. However, the membership fee is high. Cons: 1) Sometimes 2-day shipping fails to deliver in two days. 2) Amazon Prime only offers very limited choices for free music and movies, considering the membership fee. 3) Amazon Prime does not cover free returns for all Prime eligible items. For instance, I needed an immune boost product when I was very sick, but the item was delivered on the third day. I couldn't wait and got something else. However, the item delivered was not eligible for free returns. 4) There are more and more products on Amazon that are sold and shipped by sellers in China. The quality of these items is very questionable most of the time, and the shipping time is ridiculously long. I'm not saying we shouldn't purchase anything from China, but that being said, at least it should have a filter function for buyers to choose. I purchased a fall dress for my daughter and it didn't tell me where the item will be shipped from nor give me a tracking number, so I waited for over a month (already lost track of time since it took too long -- maybe 5~6 weeks) to receive it. The weather was already winter-like around Thanksgiving, so I don't see the point of keeping the dress as my daughter will outgrow it very soon. Bummer!! 5) The search engine of Amazon fails to deliver only the results you want -- it somehow gives a lot of junks when crossing your key words, and I don't know why. On the contrary, I feel eBay does a better job on this. 6) Amazon should make itself more visible on Google shopping if its search engine has flaws. It is very frustrating to be not able to find the real products neither from Amazon nor Google shopping. Due to the reasons above, I'm giving 3 or 4 stars for Amazon.

I have 2 major problems with Amazon and those are: 1: I am an Amazon Prime member yet I pay 100$(basically) to be so while they do promotions for new people to join for half the rate. I believe Prime members should get a deal from that as well. We've been loyal to Amazon and it is unfair to charge newbies way less than we pay yearly. Maybe they could lower or give a small/whatever refund for those promotions to current Amazon Prime members. 2: Another Prime issue. I'm paying so much for Prime, but I can't watch my films in HD because they won't change their player. It's so annoying to watch shows in standard when you're paying for HD and I'm not going to switch to other browsers every time I want to watch a show that happens to be on Amazon. 3: (Not a MAJOR issue, but an issue none-the-less. Amazon seems to be very pricey and just to keep getting more and more so even for Prime members. Usually what's on Amazon, I can get MUCH cheaper on Ebay or some other site. 4: Please check the reviews people give for items and movies because some times they are NOT reviewing the item, but the seller. This totally ruins the review value. I can't trust the overall review because some idgit is saying "they sent the box to me bent"....that has ZERO to do with the product at hand. Someone really needs to get on that one. Pluses and why it got a 4 star:  1: The free shipping is awesome. I love not having to deal with that.  2: The majority of the time their customer service is excellent...like the best. Only one time did I have to deal with a bad one and I just went to another one and they fixed my problem pronto. 3: It has a lot of Prime freebies that I love (but it could stand to make some more of it's movies and TV shows free for Prime Members). 4: It's pretty easy to navigate. 5: I bought a 6 cartridge litter box from members on the site two times and I was sent ONLY ONE two times....Amazon refunded me and let me keep the one that I did get instead of forcing me to go through the trouble of sending it back when it was a huge error on the side of the seller and the boxes are quite large. It would've been too much of a waste of my time. I paid over 70$ each time for 6 boxes.

I have Amazon Prime and it makes shopping on this website even better. I occasionally compare deals on Amazon and eBay, and retail stores to see which have better prices. Sometimes, Amazon isn't the most inexpensive, but if there's a situation that an item is, the Prime Shipping is extremely useful. The customer service is very helpful. It's overall a very friendly experience and extremely easy to use. There are some minor things I'd like to mention: 1. Pet Items: Maybe not just this category, but there are items that cannot be returned with no explanation. When I called up customer service, a CSR told me that some items "just can't be returned" even if the return policy never said anything about that. I asked him if there's a way to tell (for next time) and he tells me "no". Why? That's just strange and inconvenient. 2. Seller: If you think Amazon is more generous to you than eBay as a seller, they're not. They have their own policy to refund buyers for any reason just like eBay. Fees are not much less, although it depends on the category. Ebay is just a flat 15% (plus Paypal fees), so Amazon may win on the fee calculations. But, don't expect all buyers to be reasonable as I realize Amazon customers assume that there are no third-party sellers and are often impatient, demanding and hostile when there's an issue; even more hostile than eBay buyers. 3. There really should be a non-Add-On and a non-Amazon Fresh price. I wanted to purchase two different items that were only Add-On and Amazon Fresh. No other listing offers it even if it meant raising the price. Really disappointing; I wouldn't have mind to pay extra. 4. Two-Day Prime Shipping does NOT include the handling time, which can range anywhere between 1-5 days. I purchased an item that took 5 days to "handle" and then two days Prime shipping. Honestly, I could get amazing prices for certain items on Amazon, and best of all, some retail stores price-match if its shipped and sold by Amazon. I have used this website consistently every month for random purchases. There are really good prices and other times, maybe not so much. Its definitely worth having around.
It never fails Amazon and Ebay always pull through,Always very prompt service, Can't go wrong.

Good morning fellow jabbers. I want to give you the follow up on Amazon. I was contacted by several people from Amazon. First there was Jada a a lazy lazy non caring who wanted me to do all the leg work then she would perhaps be able to help me. Next came Linda an excellent Amazon employee who knows how to treat Amazon customers. She asked me for nothing, took the initiative to rectify the problem. Ordered me a new car cover. Spoke to me like I had a BRAIN. An example of an employee who goes the extra mile to assist the customer. KUDOS TO LINDA (Customer rep.) And KUDOS to Amazon for having the sense to hire Linda. I am once again a satisfied customer.. THANK YOU FELLOW JABERS FOR READING MY STORY. GOD BLESS EACH AND EVERY ONE OF YOU. Dallas Yvonne

I do probably 90% of my shopping on Amazon. It is always my first stop for anything I need. I love the prices. I like that part of my purchase goes to my favorite charity. I like not having to go to a store - or several - to get what I need. I like the fast delivery rates and the subscription services for things I need regularly. My ONLY complaints, which is why it's only 4 stars instead of 5, are (1) they seriously waste a LOT of supplies packing small items in large boxes and not combining orders to a single address and (2) over the past two years, the rate of errors, non-delivery, and defective items has increased dramatically. I realize that it is due to the volume but, given that, I think they need to re-visit their return and replacement policies because its become very hard to get replacements and/or refunds when something goes wrong for most of the things I buy. Still the biggest bang for my buck online as far as I'm concerned.

My state has an implied warranty law, the Attorney General did a tv segment stating that no need for extended warranty, and if companies don't honor the state warranty, they are in non-compliance. It took me a while and also had to provide the law and they finally refunded the full amount.   For the most part I have had good luck, and not to many issues with needed to use refunds or replacement. i buy a lot of stuff from this site, but i find more often then not the shipping is the most irritating process. especially now that you have to buy $49 worth of stuff to get free shipping.  when you order something, i find when its free shipping, that it will often take an entire week before they get around to ordering it and sending it. i live near a hub, i should be able to get it all much faster. i'm certain they do this to make the prime look better, but i think that's over priced. unless i'm shipping bags of cement and tires, i don't think i'll ever get to a $100 in shipping.  another thing is the cart, while it will hold your items forever, if its out of stock, it kicks it out, i've almost forgotten to order important things because it did do that. and when it does do that, and you add it back to the cart, it may not be from the same company. it might be more money, or it may be used (as one item they sent me was). searching is becoming much harder, it finds things i never typed in. i would rather see - we could not find that exact item, here are some things related to it. but more times than not it will show totally random things. they use titles as keywords, and many people spam them. they allow reviews from anyone - even people who never bought it - always make sure it says - verified, or you may be seeing a fake review. they do have a great refund policy though, they have come through each time. but its tricky to find their contact some times. ---Mike Savad http://www.MikeSavad.com

I am an Amazon fan. I live in a small town and for exotic items like a stainless steel pet fountain, or electronic items I need to go on line. I've rarely had an issue with anything I bought on Amazon, and when I did, they resolved in really quickly. My only negatives are that not everything is available via Prime, and Amazon is definitely NOT always the most economical option...but you pay for the convenience of having things delivered to your door, I guess. My other issue is with selling books on Amazon. I've done this for several years with little problems, but recently, I listed a pair of books that were brand new, but had been at a bookstore for a long time and never sold. The ISBN showed the publishing date, and I stated the year of publication in the listing details. Both books dealt with professional photography, and the contents were still valid. The buyer got all bent out of shape about the fact that books were older (although they were brand spanking new) and complained to Amazon...who found in his favor. He got his money back, and was to return the books to me, but he never did that, and Amazon did nothing about it. Seems they're like eBay, and all about the buyers, but want to do nothing for sellers.

I have found the reviews and the review system on Amazon to be a great help in understanding many products and services. If I take the time to read what regular people have to share, I usually always learn something new and useful. The problem with the internet is that it is a bottomless pit of raw info and has very little context and wisdom is hard to find.  Without wisdom, we are all shooting in the dark.  The availability of real user reviews and people's real opinions, as various as they are, is a small ray of light in a dark forest.  Since everyone sees things from a different perspective, it is often difficult to weed out the truth about something, but if you read enough comments, sometimes patterns start to emerge.  No other company offers as much depth in actual user comments, although this site, sitejabber, is a notable exception. People have wisdom and most people are decent.  If all companies allowed us the freedom to exchange our honest experiences, and the software would allow us to search a little better and also to collate the results, it would be a good day for consumers and a bad day for ruthless companies selling low quality trash.  So my Hat is off to Amazon. There is a reason most people use them and that is because they are the most reputable company out there.  If other companies followed their example, it would be a better world.

I am a U.S. citizen that is retired and living in Mexico. Amazon has a site here amazon.com.mx but it is really bad. The prices are sky-high as compared to the U.S. site and many things are listed as not available/out-of-stock. The thing is I have frequent family visits so I buy things on the U.S. site and have stuff brought down. Their international shipping rates aren't bad either if I need something "now" but quite a few things they won't ship to Mexico. The one thing that pisses me off is I have to use my family's credit cards as my credit cards are Mexican and are in pesos. Amazon gives very unfair exchange rates when they convert from U.S. dollars to Mexican pesos. Having said all that, they have everything, their prices are good, their Website is very well designed and easy to use, they are nice people in my experience and have excellent Support. I didn't rate them perfect because of the exchange rate issue, but they really are a good company to work with.

I've made a number of purchases on Amazon India and about 80% of my experiences have been very positive. Mostly the products are as promised and arrive quickly. In one or two cases they outer packaging of the items was peeling or dingy, but the products themselves were good. When I did receive damaged products or I didn't receive the products I had paid for, I contacted Amazon customer care and they immediately refunded my money. Only two points of improvement for Amazon India: 1) Many of the prices on your site are so obnoxiously, ridiculously high. I'm talking about pricing something that sells in the US for $10 (~600 rupees) at Rs.20,000. I waste time on your site because so many of the products I want are at these "scammy" prices. Ruins the whole shopping experience and makes me feel like I'm in some cheap fake marketplace full of scamsters look to swindle customers. 2) It is very hard to contact Amazon Customer Care. The first time I did it, it took me 30 minutes to figure out how to email/chat with customer care. There needs to be a prominant link for that.

There is this flaw in the instant pay system. If during the previous 60 days you accidentally included some item in your shopping cart, which you did not in fact purchase, the next time you purchase anything these items magically re-appear and if you are not very careful you will pay for them! They also take no responsibility for most 3rd party sellers which has become most of the business. The function which suggest other products based on previous purchases actually works and I find it more helpful than others.

I have never made a better decision about something, I just had to come back and share. Before I bumped into Glestore Men's 3-pack Modal Soft Boxer. I was looking for something that could enable me to be free and yet give me assurance that I'm totally covered- you know, without having to remind me I'm carrying a package when I walk and this babie right here was designed just for that! I have to admit that the quality is at its best, the design that takes the body's nature, not to mention the price. They had all these different sizes and colours to choose from so i didn't have to try so hard to find something ideal. With a smart combination of 95% Modal and 5% spandex the absorption capacity is quite high, even higher than cotton fiber which is about 50%, i have done a couple of wears but so far not felt suffocated or soaked, even during my work-outs they have proven to be breathable, this definitely spells quality and for me to place my wallet on a product, there has to be some good quality in it. These underwear have been nothing short of comfortable, and quite soft which is a great feeling not having to be coursed by rough jeans, they are also slim fit and can be worn under any material. Though I'm kind of wondering what you had in mind for us with this product because it falls more on the sexy side which is a plus anyway, because either way you look good both with and without pants. They also cover a good section of the thigh and in them I don't even feel close to naked. It's almost like wearing a second skin but with a good fitting for your junk, meaning good chocolate with a good wrapper. The waist is another thing that really got points from me, it's firm but not too tight and the fitting's perfect especially around the groin. I have bought a few different brands before that I won't mention here for obvious reasons but some of them actually make you feel like you're wearing a female swimsuit--and sadly, I kid you not. I have seen far more expensive brands, this kind of explains why a lot of females have a notion on men scratching their 'groins' publicly, the itching comes as a result of wearing underwear that's too tight which would obviously bring that region too close to the body, which should not happen anywhere in the face of the universe-no really, it shouldn't. This also does not mean they should be let to hang free for reasons best known to us. All men irrespectable of their social standing, lifestyle, political power, age or.. or.. forget it, deserve good quality, well-fitting underwear and the Glestore Mens 3-pack modal Soft Boxer provided just that for me. In my experience-that is; since I started buying underwear on my own which is a long while, i have so far not found few that can compete with the comfort of your everyday wear of Glestore Mens 3-pack Modal Soft Boxer. At first I tried this brand out with a 1-pack but it obviously didn't take long to purchase the 3-pack. One thing that probably sucks about my life is that I actually don't have enough time for some of these little but time consuming chores so I was very glad it turned out to be machine washable, (can't do it most of the time) but presumably just a few machine washes and mostly hand washing we'll do, but that definitely worked for me. These days it's very rare to get anything good with an affordable price tag but your prices are like hitting the jackpot, the average cost of the Glestore Mens 3-pack Modal Soft Boxer ranges from about $6 to $9 on average. I found this price very fair to say the least and this partly gave me all the more reason to buy these superior undies. The return policy for some sizes is quite cool if for example someone bought a pair or more but the wearer was not present or aware during purchase, I guess they'd most certainly have to be unsealed at return but nevertheless I'm glad I went shopping around and discovered something different and unique. This product is the best bet you have in the male category and I will definitely be making future purchases if you keep both the quality and the price unbeatable. Hope my words can help you guys to find your style. Thank you.

It had always been so very easy to manage my Kindle Fire content, borrowing and purchasing e-books, audio-books, downloading apps., etc.., Until this past month when I got in touch with Amazon regarding deleting some e-books, audio-books, hypnosis & meditations that I had purchased recently and several years ago. My storage space is running low and since all of the above mentioned items had previously been read/listened to as a medical condition reduces the amount of time I can read. printed text. Unfortunately, every inquiry that was sent Amazon (about permanently deleting the books) has been sent to Audible who has no idea how to remove the content. My only option at this point would be to delete my Kindle Fire content completely and start from scratch -- that would entail my de-registering my Kindle Fire and re-purchasing the e-books, Audio-books, hypnosis and meditations that I still want and listen to. This has been an ongoing inquiry for well over a month and I'm getting absolutely nowhere, prior to Audible's involvement in this "immersion reading" nonsense, there was no problem at all with managing my content myself through Amazon's web site. The problem appears to be that the items being referred to were prior to Audible's involvement with Amazon books and they really do not know how to delete content. Guess they didn't think that far ahead -- did they -- Thanks2Net ??

If you become a Prime member on the 3 day free trial (which I clicked on by accident), and then do not cancel this at the end of the complimentary period; you become a full member and are charged for the privilege. Amazon isn't just a place to shop online, it is a resource. I used it research products, and I rely on the reviews of books, which represent individual and independent opinion. Yes, there are a lot of reviews that are just stupid, but if you read the critically, there is a lot to be learned. When I look at a book the first thing that I do is to look at the one-star reviews. If all the bad reviews are ideologically motivated, that is a reason to take the better reviews seriously. If the bad reviews are well thought-out, detailed, and carefully reasoned, then all the predictable rave reviews are probably mere fluff.

I order from Amazon monthly. Amazon and its sellers are very reliable, including their adequate packing of fragile items that is most important to me. Incredibly fast delivery time, beating walmart.com by miles in this regard.  Wish that delivery costs from outside businesses to Prime customers were more lucid. Amazon is a great way to shop for products. I have personally never had a problem shopping here. The only problem I had with an order was that it took a very long time to arrive. It apparently came from China. Anyways, as much as Amazon can be a great place to shop, KNOW YOUR PRICES.  Just because an item is being sold on Amazon does not mean it is a good deal. I have seen some products being sold for more than they could be purchased elsewhere. For example, I buy my health and wellness products direct from the manufacturer. People are selling the same products for 300% - 400% markup. That's REDICUOUS!  For example, I purchase a super high quality moisturizer for under $10. The product has been clinically proven to be 7 times better at holding moisture than Eucerin. The problem is that the product is being sold on Amazon for over $30???!?? Sure people are buying it for that price because the product is great, but I would rather keep my money by buying it direct from the manufacturer, thank you very much.

As somebody who only purchases items from Amazon themselves (no third party sellers), I am disapointed with the amount of counterfeit items i have received. Do yourself a favor, and buy things that are easily counterfeit ( phone cases, sd cards, earbuds etc) in person. I purchased three Speck branded phone cases from amazon. They were of decent construction, but two of them cracked after being dropped from about knee height. I sent them back to speck because they were supposed to be under warranty. Speck called me and told me to send them back to who i bought them from because they were fakes. Its funny, Amazon would not take them back. Their reasoning? They do not allow returns on counterfeit goods. I purchase many things from amazon. My experience with counterfeits has not soured my overall experience with Amazon. I just caution you to buy things that are easily counterfeit in person, or better yet, just buy them straight from the manufacturer.

Amazon is hit and miss, but mostly hit. I buy from them often; several items a month on average. I have only had a few problems with them. My biggest beef is their "temporarily out of stock" description, which always means: "permanently out of stock". If you avoid these, you will most likely enjoy the cheapest prices and most reasonable shipping on the internet. If you do have a problem, their customer service department is grade A, and really do seek to satisfy their customers, which is why I buy from them so often. It also helps that shipping is free on orders over $35! They really can't be beat! (Shameless plug: check out my review of their "Alchemy Mummified Palmistry Hand Gothic". It's a truish story!)

Amazon is a good company that was once great. Their ease in ordering and paying is second to none. The problem with their current policy is they are really cutting the price using sometimes very poor quality products from overseas. Now their return policy and return procedure is again; 2nd to none. Click a couple of buttons, take a printed return form to UPS and ship it with a credit already posted back to your account. Amazon could return to greatness by doing more quality control and allowing reviews that were not only about the product but also about the company. Good luck and God bless.

I love Amazon and, since I live in a rural area, use them a lot. 98% of the time they work flawlessly. 1.5% of the time they goof but the returns process works out fine. But that last little bit is when there's a minor gaff which can be fixed easily but that fix is not in their playbook. And there's no way to get a message to a customer service person. Example is a while ago I bought an item which was battery operated (included!) and fairly large. It was also packaged in one of those terrible blown plastic things but nobody noticed that the included batteries, easily visible in the online photos and indeed through the plastic, had been pilfered. The main product was ok but I knew they would send replacement batteries if I could just let them know. But no way to communicate that. So I swallowed the cost of a couple of batteries. I know, not a big deal but what if it had been some larger problem but just as simple to fix?

Amazon usually does things right the first time. However recently my husband ordered a grooming arm for my dog grooming table which was supposed to come with a clamp. The clamp was missing. I didn't pay attention because I have a shorter arm that has the same clamp, so I just used that. When I realized my new dog is going to need both arms for grooming I asked him to order me a clamp and he said "didn't the new one come with a clamp? It was supposed to!" So sure enough, it was, and we had to file a request for a replacement. The thing is, all the seller would have had to do is send us the clamp. But instead the Amazon return/exchange process wasted money by sending us a whole new one and shipping the one with missing parts back. Why? If this is how Amazon is doing things it is totally wasting people's money. Sure it didn't cost me and didn't inconvenience me except that they showed up to pick up the one I already had, two days before the replacement came, and we said no, you have to bring us the replacement first!  But the cost for all this extra freight from such an odd process goes into the system and applies to prices across the board. Just send me the parts I need from one you already have, and defect THAT one of yours out. There has to be a way to eliminate waste there.

Update: I have changed my rating to 4 stars. Over the past (almost 4) years, I have seen Amazon go downhill. Shipping and returns remain excellent in most cases. Merchandise: has become more questionable and prices have skyrocketed. (Lookout for Outlet items in particular. Many are found on wish.com. Check it out). Clothing is super hard to pin down for quality unless you search for a particular brand. Off-brands permeate the site (when using just search parameters) with skewed sizes and questionable quality. Prices: I've seen stuff at DOUBLE the price of other online retailers (take a look at sparkling water for one). I don't use Prime anymore. It's not worth it to me. I've been a Prime member for years. I love it. I order anything from toothpaste to televisions. I only order Prime unless it's a special item. No shipping pays for itself within in the first few shipments. I furnished my entire apartment using Amazon. Very few times (out of literally hundreds) have been disappointing. My only caution: Like any other store, online or otherwise, be careful of ignoring regular or higher prices lurking among all item types. Check Walmart.com for prices on items just to be sure the free Prime shipping is not costing your more in item price. Also, love the Amazon Prime streaming video for movies and TV series. Walmart is supposed to add a similar shipping program on a pilot-program basis. We'll see.

We are continually impressed with Amazon's ability to provide stellar customer service and their Prime systems are a great value to all of us that shop online on a regular basis. We always go to the Amazon site first to see what they charge to gauge deals others are offering. We've seen people trying to sell used stuff on Craigslist for more than buying a new one would cost on Amazon! Even if you don't shop at Amazon, just them being there with their low prices, great customer service and Prime shipping, has forced other online and brick and mortar retailers to lower their prices or up their act, so kudos to them for that, if nothing else! All this having been said, they have one nagging and frustrating unacceptable issue. If you place a lot of orders they start combining them and shipping them separately and then charges with mystery dollar amounts start showing on your charge card statement that don't show up in your order history. So, then you have to call them and they explain that these two orders were combined or we did this and that and we're sorry they don't show up in your order history as they do on your credit card statement. This needs fixing! Just give me every order you charged to my credit card in my order history AS YOU CHARGED THEM so I can easily scroll through and check them off when my credit card bill arrives. PLEASE fix this Amazon - everything else is awesome!

Have been very pleased with Amazon as both a buyer and a seller. As a buyer they get what you ordered at the price that was advertised. Shipping is no hassle. One issue that I have run into is when an item is no longer made by a manufacturer. Amazon sometimes will advertise the replacement item using the product description for the old product. If you want the replacement product fine. But, if the replacement product is inferior to the original you will have a problem. Sellers run into the same problem. They aren't given the means to advertise the new product. They have to advertise the replacement item using the old item description.  As a seller they hold you to selling a quality product and making sure you get it shipped on time. You must also provide a way for the customer to track their order. The complaints I have with them as a seller is that it can be a nightmare to get all of your information on the correct screens. The screens aren't the most user-friendly. And if you don't get all of your information down you won't be paid in a timely manner.

I've been buying from Amazon.com for several years now. You can find just about anything you want, and if you price-shop around a little, you'll get a fairly good buy. The one thing I really don't like though, is that if you have Prime - as we did for while_ the shipping cost is actually built into the price of the item, making it harder to know if you got a good deal on said item or not. We ascertained this by doing internet searches on the same item using several sellers - ebay, Froogle, overstock, etc. and comparing them to Prime items on Amazon. I was surprised at what I found - that shipping seemed to be included in the price on Amazon. So buying into Prime isn't always such a good idea - maybe it's better to price-shop a bit and be patient with longer shipping times.

I rarely have an issue in ordering from Amazon and hold a Prime membership and love it. Recently I ordered a bag of dog food and paid $10 extra for overnight shipping because I needed it ASAP. After waiting two days with no food delivered and no update to the shipping I wrote an email to customer service asking for assistance. They replied quickly with an email that was not a canned response. The agent investigate with the shipper and found out the delay, refunded the extra shipping cost and then followed up the next day to make certain the food arrived. It was the perfect response in that situation and showed a willingness to go above and beyond to please a customer.

I have had an Amazon account for many years and never a bad experience. Last spring I wanted to catch up on a TV series that was streamed free on Amazon's Prime service. With an eye toward this Christmas's shipping requirements, I purchased the Prime service. The savings in shipping to my scattered family alone has paid for the service, and I have access to some good TV shows that I can't find anywhere else. *** Editing *** I have lost confidence in their ability to meet their shipping commitments, especially the "free next day delivery with orders over $35". 5 times I have ordered for next day delivery between my home and work accounts, twice it has arrived as promised. In one case, I bought an additional item to get the next day delivery because I had an immediate need for an item at work. It took 9 days to arrive. I have always gotten what I expected as far as the items have been concerned, but I will never trust their rapid delivery promises again. I dropped 1 star from my previous review due to this.

I love Amazon. I think it's better than eBay most of the time. With Amazon I can get all kinds of great CDs, DVDs and video games for really low prices. What I like better about this than eBay, is with eBay you have to compete for everything and the infamous eBay Snipers almost always win. Plus eBay sellers are allowed to add little stipulations to auctions that contractually force the would-be-buyer to agree to in order to make a purchase. With Amazon, none of that is a problem because they don't let it work that way. The ONLY things I have to say negative about Amazon is that the sellers can't combine shipping prices which means if you buy 2 or more CDs from a seller, and they only have to spend $3 to ship them, you still have to pay $2.98 for shipping, for each CD. So the shipping on Amazon can you from a cart sub-total value of $5 and you end up with a $30 total. I also with sellers had to leave feedback for buyers as well. But with the way Amazon buying works it really doesn't matter. That's my ONLY gripe with Amazon. Other than that 1 thing they kill eBay in every single category you can think of. I talk to Amazon reps via-chat anytime I need an answer. Good luck contacting eBay reps!!! Amazon I give 4 / 5 only because the shipping will bite you in the butt!!!

So when your product comes late or you where over charged Amazon is not at fault. When you go to order something it will say where you are ordering the product from. If you have had a bad experiences with a product than you know not to order from that manufacturer again. If you don't pay attention to the site you order it from its your fault not Amazon. Amazon is a website that allows individuals from all over to purchase a variety of items that may or may not be out of 'reach'. Due to distances, amazon enables people to purchase almost anything as they will ship it right out to you. They have provided people with a service by bringing the products right into their homes and personal spaces, something other competitors cannot do without bringing the customer to them.  Amazon is VERY effective because it cares of customers. They ensure delivery, provide promotions, and offer a variety of products for purchasing. As movie stores, such as Blockbusters and Movie Galleries, are becoming slim to none in existence, many people have resorted to online options to watch movies. Many people prefer the online option to view their movies because it is often times free or cheaper than renting one at a store. Also having to be home or near a tv at the exact time your favorite tv series airs its newest episode is no longer an issue with these web 2.0 tools since they have both movies and tv episodes for their users. This instant availability has definitely been a major pro for users and is probably one of the main reasons movie stores are going out of business. I found three web 2.0 sites that people can use to watch their favorite tv shows and movies. I took into account the websites' affordability, accessibility, reliability, and more to create my reviews. Amazon's instant videos are very easy to navigate. There is a search bar and also categories to make it easier for the user to find what they are looking for. Another pro is that the prices for each movie or tv episode is clearly displayed. Amazon Prime is an option the site offers in which you can become a Prime member for $79 a year which allows you to have access to thousands of free movies and episodes that are have no additional fee as compared to having to make a purchase each time you decide to use Amazon instant videos. A major con is that there are no free options to this site and that there must be some kind of purchase made before watching an episode or movie. However the cost is relatively cheap and affordable. I would recommend this website.

Always the go-to place when shopping. A few small issues remain such as sorting by price which basically doesn't work, and also searches tend to bring up many not so relevant results. They also collect sales tax in New York. My note about sales tax follows: Amazon COLLECTS sales tax; they do not CHARGE sales tax. Even if Amazon would not collect it, you would still be obligated by law to pay. It's just that no one actually does and so the states are going after the sellers to collect. Most states will have a section on the tax return where the taxpayer is supposed to indicate the amount of goods purchased for which no sales tax was paid - and then pay the tax. The issue is that if a seller does not have nexus in a certain state, they can basically tell the state to shove off since the state has no jurisdiction over them. The state would then have the option of banning the company from doing business there but then would run the risk of having the Interstate Commerce Commission come afer them, not to mention violating Federal and possibly even Constitutional laws. It basically comes down to a game of chicken between the states and the companies where the state tries to show that the company has nexus there and the company tries to show that it doesn't. Amazon is the biggest target due to its size and potential tax revenue to the states. They gave in to New York and is slowly caving in to other states. This will go on until the Federal Government gets involved and Congress passes some type of law governing the collection of sales tax. Or a case may make it to the Supreme Court with the same effect.

My fiancee and I routinely order all manner of goods from Amazon.com.  First the pros: 1. Great selection:  We've ordered everything from roto-tillers, books and MP3s to a garment bag for her wedding dress, all at prices that are better than nearly every reputable retail outlet. 2. Solid packaging:  Unlike most sellers, we haven't run into any issues with damage due to inadequate protection in shipping. 3. Good Marketplace: A wide variety of accredited sellers, giving you even more comparison and shopping power, all on one site. Although the overall experience has been good, I have a few minor issues to note: 1.Beware free shipping: This is kind of a crap-shoot. Sometimes, you'll have your items in a few days, however, there is no rhyme or reason to what gets shipped in a timely fashion. We've had an order of several books shipped from CA arrive in MA in two days, and we've had electronics shipped from KY take nearly 3 weeks to the same address. If you need the items quickly, ignore the free shipping option, and decide if the cost to have the items shipped quickly offsets the slightly lower price. For example, the last round of electronics was slightly cheaper, because of the free shipping, on amazon.com than on newegg.com, with newegg's shipping costs. However, had we ordered them from newegg, we'd have had them in 3 days, and amazon to 20.  2. Be careful with one-click ordering: Although useful, and I think required to order MP3 files, make sure you shut this back off. I accidentally pre-ordered a book using one-click, and didn't even realize it until the book showed up 2 months later! 3. Read the reviews of non-amazon sellers: Although the marketplace is great, make sure you check into the reviews of any non-amazon seller on the site. There are some shady sellers out there, but at least amazon leaves the bad reviews up, unlike some sites (Virgin Mobile and Beckett come to mind)

1. Video On Demand: they are trying to compete with netflix/itunes/etc, but here is the problem...while they do have a great selection and reasonable prices the quality of the video cannot even begin to compare to that of netflix or itunes right now. Plus they somehow lack the ability to buffer the video, so if your connection slows during playback the entire video stops. This never has happened to me on netflix or itunes. Did I mention this was on a T1 line? They give you the option to download the movie to your PC if the connection is too slow, but here is the catch, if you started watching the video already you have to pay AGAIN to download the video. So make sure you test out their connection before you pay for their VOD services, my T1 line was too slow for them. I give them a meh rating as of 12/2010 but hope in the future they get their act together. They clearly rolled this out before it was ready in hopes to gain market share of the VOD services.  2. Kindle: here I give amazon a full heart, for books they are doing it right. Very seemless and easy to use. Almost magical in the way you can be reading a book within minutes.  3. books/DVDs: here again they deserve a full heart. fast service and I do much of my xmas shopping here.

It is 1914 in Hollywood and the craze there is the "flickers", silent motion pictures. The biggest star is Mary Pickford, "America's Sweetheart". With her long golden curls and the sweetest smiles, her fans adore her. Mary has been sole support of her mother and siblings since she was 8 years old and she will do anything to keep her popularity and wrung on the ladder of success. Never had time for a childhood, or an education, Mary has strong work ethics and is savvy in charming her powerful bosses who rule Hollywood. When she meets Frances Marion, a "wanna be writer" for the Silver Screen, Mary tries to talk Frances into becoming an actress but fails. They become close friends and form a personal and professional bond that lasts a lifetime. They become trailblazers fighting for women's rights in the film industry, and both achieve awards, power, the love of a lifetime, and great wealth. Mary Pickford married handsome mega-star, Douglas Fairbanks and they became the Royal Couple. They lived at Pickfair, the elegant 18 acre estate in Beverly Hills. They entertained often and lavishly but it was not the quiet, peaceful, together forever life, Mary dreamed of. In the end, Mary lost Fairbanks and lived at Pickfair alone as a recluse. Fran Marion, too, had the love of her life, marrying Fred until he passed away. Fran became the highest paying screenwriter in Hollywood.  A dedicated fan of Melanie Benjamin, two of her books, "THE AVIATOR'S WIFE;, and 'THE LAST CHRISTMAS IN PARIS', are two of my favorites.. Ms. Benjamin writes sterling historical fiction and her research is impeccable. Films have always been of keen interest to me and GIRLS IN THE PICTURE is a riveting story that takes us both in front of the camera and behind the scenes with a candid description of the fascinating happenings of that era and the sensational people who lived it. My admiration for both Mary Pickford and Frances Marion for never giving up but reaching the heights but not without heartbreak. This book is highly recommended by me. You will love it. I did! My thanks to Random House e-newsletter giveaway that I was lucky to win. Thank you and Thank you to Melanie Benjamin for another winner. Bravo!

I came to online purchasing late in life. I was very hesitant to put my credit card info out on the web. Plus I always preferred dealing with brick and mortar merchants. If I had an issue I could walk in to the store and resolve my problem. Who knew how online stores would handle customer service. Well Amazon quickly sold me on online purchasing. Both of my kids and most of my grandkids are in other states. Anyone who who has tried to ship anything knows that shipping costs are outrageous. So I tried making a few purchases from Amazon. I always bought enough to get free shipping. I didn't have Prime at first. The first time I had to contact customer service I was so pleased with outcome I decided to stay with them. I'll give you an example of Amazon's customer service. I was given a Kindle Fire as a gift. It was purchased from a Major Electronic Chain Store. Within the first couple of weeks I started having an issue with it. I phoned the Major Electronic Chain Store and spoke to one of their customer service people. I explained the issue to her, giving her the date of purchase and the fact that I did have the receipt. Her response was that I would have to bring it in and if it was something covered under the warranty they would look as t it. But if not then I was pretty much SOL. I had explained in detail to her what the issue was. It did not have anything to do with abuse of the Kindle. It had a clear operating issue. She just kept to the same not interested attitude. I told her to not worry about it. I would call Amazon. But that I would never set foot in her store again again. To this day I have not. I did call Amazon. I made it very clear that the Kindle had been purchased from this other very unhelpful store. They did not care. They sent me a shipping label to return it to Amazon and as shipped me a brand new Kindle. Every time I have ever had to phone Amazon's customer service they have gone above and beyond to make sure that whatever issue I am having is solved. I do have Prime now and I HIGHLY recommend it to everyone. I can spend over a hundred dollars shipping one box to my kids. So the cost of Prime is a bargain. Not only do I have free shipping all year, but free books, movies, and all kinds of other things. I love this company.

I have been using Amazon for many years, and I must say that shopping with Amazon is not only convenient, but they usually have items found elsewhere at a lower price!! My daughter has Amazon Prime, and I think that this service is completely a worthwhile investment. Amazon Prime assures that usually anything marked with a "Amazon Prime Symbol" will ship to you in two days or less, and the shipping is completely free. Many of the Amazon Prime products for sale also come with "Free Returns". Let me explain. If you make a purchase with Amazon Prime, and the product is listed as "Free Returns"........you have absolutely no risk in placing your order. When your order arrives with two-day free shipping, and it isn't what you thought it was, or it doesn't fit properly, you just request a return. This then takes you to a page to print out a shipping label for free return shipping of your order, with a refund quickly following the return. How can you beat that for worry-free online shopping??? The pricing on Amazon, on almost any product you can think of, is for the most part, less than purchasing from a brick and mortar store, and certainly less expensive than making your purchase on a different website!!! It pays to know your prices first....as Amazon is sometimes (rarely) the same price or a higher price than other competitors. I use traditional stores to go and touch and check-out an item.....then I go to Amazon to place my order for the same exact product at a substantial savings!!! Amazon is awesome!!! Don't just take my word for it......give it a try!!! Go with Amazon Prime......and if you are not happy with the pricing or service, Amazon will refund your Prime membership in full....no questions asked!!!! Furthermore, there are products on Amazon that you would never find for sale in a normal, run of the mill store. The variety of similar products gives you a wider choice of exactly what you want, and exactly what you don't want!!! For example, go to Home Depot to purchase an electrical meter. You may have two or three choices....that's it folks. Now, go onto Amazon.....type in electric meter....and you may happen to have anywhere from ten to fifty choices with complete descriptions and directions. And, I can almost guarantee that you can find an electric meter at a substantially lower price!!!!! Got to love it!!!!!!

Today, many companies are going virtual to keep up with the times. It improves speed and accessibility for all consumers. Although there are many different companies, Amazon takes the cake. Amazon is the best online retailer because of the simplicity to use their website, the speed of their deliveries, and most of all their affordability. To get started with Amazon, all you need is an email and a PayPal, credit, or debit card to make a purchase. They walk you through the entire process making sure you know exactly what you are doing. To shop, all you do is click on what you want and put it in the shopping cart. Once you are finished, you go to your cart and check out. They have standard shipping for most items but if you sign up for Amazon Prime, some items get free speedy delivery, next day delivery, or even same day delivery. Every day there are deals that you can get just by going on their deals page. If you are an Amazon Prime member, you are eligible to get discounts and deals just for being a member. Amazon is the best online retailer because they know how to use the internet to their advantage. Best of all, they work towards making each customer happy and work hard for each and every one.

TWO PART REVIEW; 1) Sellers of gently used goods, lend me your ears!     NO longer do you have to wait for an auction to end and pray that your item fetched at least the cost to ship it to its new owner. Amazon is just like being able to sell your items among the premium giants of the online retail businesses........! AT A NEARLY RETAIL PRICE!!!  (That's right I s%&t you not my friends. I wouldn't lie to you, I personally swear by Amazon sellers market and have made close to ten thousand dollars selling used items that I referbished from various sources. Items that would have gone for at least 25%-50% less on ebay and even lower on Facebook or Craigslist.) Did the Facebook reference catch your atention, nearly everyone has Facebook and lover the local buys. But the price is garage sale level and let's face it the market is limited to a few thousand at most. Amazon is nationwide/global and Amazon allows you you view all other products that are the same as the one you are listing and price your according to your competitors prices.  That means if anyone in the entire country is interested in a product that you happen to be selling you will have play in Amazon.  Quick seller? I am! And I priced my listings from $1.00-$5.00 below the lowest priced item(which is barely 10%lower than at Walmart or kohl's and even Best Buy) insuring my product would sell to the first frugal consumer interested in the product.   2)Buyers of o line merchandise!      Amazon has a very strict customer satisfaction percentage requirement for its sellers I think it's like 98.99% positive review rate. With the exception that you can accept the following: You want free shipping? Meet requirements when you checkout items. Whether it's 25 or 49 dollars. Also check that your items come with the possibility of free shipping, otherwise it will NOT count towards free shipping. (Irritating, I know) Not all of your products will be delivered when scheduled. I know that may suck, but that is why Amazon allows you to contact sellers to ensure nothing happens to your products along the way. Some products may never find their way to your home. Which is even more irritating, but the first thing you should do is go on Amazon to contact the seller or file a complaint to Amazon directly. Every time this has happened to me I got promised a full refund within a day or two with no questions asked. (Refunds take time to get to your account. Which implies it will take longer for Amazon to process your refund, it may take up to two weeks to process the full refund) AND SOME PRODUCTS WILL BE ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE BUT THATS WHY WE MUST READ REVIEWS VERY VERY CAREFULLY AND DEMAND (or ask politely) THAT THE SELLER TAKES THE SAID PRODUCT BACK. Some sellers may be very good at making sure you get the product you wanted. Every once in a while I get a card from a seller I buy from, it's handwritten by her, she makes it clear that I can contact her with any questions or concerns about the product. Those types of sellers are the ones that deserve a review, or really any seller that makes sure your product is in ideal condition when it arrives. Make sure you review! Especially if your experience exceeds or falls below your expectations, honestly a lot of customers look at stars and reviews before they buy a product, be sure to encourage/discourage them accordingly.  Last note: If you decide to purchase a product, make sure it's not overpriced or too cheap. Overpricing is an obvious issue which I probably don't have to explain But some products that are underpriced are such terrible quality, and even the sellers might not be all the great either. (That's why you ought to look at reviews!!!!) I can't recommend this site enough for people who wish to shop online.

They have been quick to respond to any problems even with private sellers and refund or replace. I always check reviews from private sellers before buying and never go for anyone with a rating below 96% positive. Returns are easy. I've recently subscribed to Amazon prime, thought I would give it a go for a year. I'm loving it. Lots of TV shows and movies, as good if not better than Netflix, free kindle books, and free music with Amazon music and best of all you no longer need to meet the £20 threshold for free next day delivery. All that for £79 a year, what's not to like

2 Incidents that demonstrate this for me: Oct 2016--I ordered a 45 lbs dumbbell. After I checked the tracking notice, the delivery info said 43 lbs. No biggie, but I messaged Amazon that they might update the page and let others know this can happen, a weight be off a pound or two. The rep responded by apologizing, refunding the payment, and telling me to keep the dumbbell. Outstanding. Feb 2017--Ordered a nice little bookcase from Amazon fulfillment. It came, I assembled it and the middle shelf--the screws didn't line up right. It's not a huge problems, still have the others shelves, just 4 instead of 5. When I sent feedback to support, the rep offered a full refund if I sent it back or (as it was still functioning and useful) she would refund me half of my purchase. I was appreciative of this.

Many of us had hihg end sneakers, sport products etc. All of a sudden we could not sell theses items without an approval requiring a $1000 application to sell brand name but it was not a guaranteed approval. If not approved than you lost the whole $1000 dollars. I did not get stuck with inventory but many of my friends then had to sell on Ebay or some other site. Huge disappoint and financial loss just before Christmas. ??? So for a seller it is a great site to purchase from but for a seller your account can be terminated or put on hold for very minor infractions??? It is a great site but a site to be very careful of if you are a seller.

Amazon order number : 114-8083188-1541855. Macys order number: 1391458161..for those who wish to research the validity of this review. I was expecting a shipment from both Macy's and Amazon.com on the same date on about the 15th of March 2017. I received emails that the items we're delivered but upon getting home from work nothing was on the porch as they usually are and I've been a frequent customer to both companies for years.  I immediately called both and both Macy's and Amazon seemed to understand and show interest in helping however Macy's customer service must be in Vietnam because I could barely understand them. They both told me I'd be issued a refund so I'm happy at this point.  However at 8pm on this same date the items from Macys showed up on the porch and several days later at about the same time the item from Amazon showed up. Obviously a delivery error because the UPS info noted left with lady but no lady lives at my address. Although unsure where it was left they we're honest enough to return it to me.  I called both Macy's and Amazon immediately to correct the credits and here's what I found. Amazon actually was truthful and issued the refund while Macy's showed no record of any refund and days later sent me a letter saying because of the shipper note (left with lady) they we're unable to issue a refund.  Good thing this mysterious lady that they spoke of at an unknown address and no signature was honest. My point is it's good to know if there is a problem Amazon is willing to help while Macy's on the other hand will not be getting anymore orders simply because they chose to blame the customer for the shipping error. EVEN THEN, if there is a problem,my experience is that Amazon will take care of you. I've had to return items - Amazon paid return shipping.  I've gotten items that were defective and the seller disappeared. Amazon gave me a refund. I've had warranty issues with third party seller - Amazon made good on my purchase. THe bottom line is that I am pretty sure I can rely on Amazon to correct any problems, at their expense, not mine. That makes them a great online store.

I buy virtually everything online (from TVs to automobile tires, to door hardware, to food items), and Amazon has been an essential tool for getting what I want easily, quickly, and usually at or near the best possible prices. There's no one out there doing as good a job of supplying almost any product imaginable than Amazon.com. But....you don't always get the best price, and all too often their collection of sales tax makes them uncompetitive. So I use Amazon to easily find exactly what I want, and then I make sure there aren't less expensive purchase options available within Amazon. And that's what makes Amazon such a great site and tool--they help you find the cheapest deals if you use them wisely. For example, after searching the most obvious prices available on Amazon, you need to find and click on the Available from These Sellers link to see your options. Those options almost always allow you to place an order with independent 3rd party sellers who don't collect sales tax, and many also provide free shipping, or qualify for Amazon Prime shipping benefits. But don't stop there, you also need to click the See All Buying Options button. That's where you may find your item being sold with free 2-day shipping, for example, (which might otherwise never have been available if you hadn't searched a bit further).  I also have an Amazon Prime membership which saves time and money on shipping while also giving me Amazon Prime movies and TV programs, including some great original series. Is everything less expensive using Amazon? No, it's not, but searching that item within Amazon and outside of Amazon provides you almost effortless comparative pricing. So deciding where to get the best overall deal becomes extremely easy. And whenever I'm in doubt and prices are almost identical, I'll usually play it "safe" by going with Amazon so that I can easily return an item on a hassle-free basis. That in itself has been one of the best features of Amazon.com. Remember that Amazon makes buying online extremely easy, but it's real value is as a price comparison tool for finding the best deal possible in the shortest amount of time. Although Amazon.com may not always prove to be the least expensive online seller, the website makes finding the best possible deals incredibly easy. Add to that their hassle-free return policy, and they absolutely deserve the highest ratings possible.

They have upped the minimum price for free shipping over the years, but I guess that's to be expected as costs rise. However, there are still sellers on Amazon that offer free shipping, and depending on where you live, sometimes no tax. You can pay a variety of ways, get e-books instantly, and make wish lists easily. You can even order with one click if you choose to set up that option. Amazon doesn't always have the lowest prices, but often does, so check around online and even in your local stores before you order. Some businesses in your town may even price match Amazon if you ask and their policy permits it. One thing I have noticed is that prices can fluctuate wildly, sometimes even the same day, so if you find what you want at a great price you might ought to get it--it might cost more tomorrow (or less)! There is almost no category of merchandise Amazon or one of their sellers doesn't offer, so browse and refer to them often.

The hammock feature helps keep the dogs from sliding down into the footrest area, while also providing a slight barrier to help keep them from climbing into the front of the car. The fact that dog hair is not getting all over her nice leather seats doesn't hurt either. While I did receive this item at a discount on the grounds that I would review it up receipt and use I can honestly say that my opinions in regards to it have not been swayed by that fact. I have been using Amazon for about 15 years now and I have seen Amazon go through a number of changes. I am currently an Amazon Prime member and since I buy a lot of items from Amazon, the two day free shipping is something that keeps me coming back. I must admit however that I also bounce each purchase off of Ebay because you can often find cheaper items there and you do not have to usually pay the tax there. Also Ebay offers Ebay Bucks for most purchases that accumulate quarterly and you can use those bucks towards any purchase sometimes getting things for free. The shipping usually takes a few days longer to get to you but if it is something I don't need right away, I will go to Ebay instead of Amazon. It's also usually a little tougher if you have a problem with a purchase because the hoops you have to jump through at Ebay, make it more of a pain that Amazon which is very liberal in it's return policy. With Amazon now trying to get into groceries, I cannot wait to see how this shakes out.

When you request a return, they send you an email with a shipping form to print. I use Amazon a lot, but I also do a 'google' search for the product to be sure it is the best price. I love Amazon. Since I despise shopping, this is a great option. Jeff Besos is a genius, of course. His idea for customer service relations is a business model every on-line seller should use: generally, no questions asked return. And the response time is within seconds of asking for a return phone call or email. The only thing I do not like is a part of the Amazon Prime program. I've found that when I use Prime to shop, the item is generally higher than if I bought it through another vendor. The trick may be their free 2-day shipping promise. Other vendors may take longer to ship, but the cost is often much less. For example, if you look for a book and it's $18 on Amazon with free shipping, you may be able to find the same one for $5 plus shipping of about $3.. That could be a lot less expense for you. But the "free shipping" idea makes the buyer more likely to purchase it through Amazon. Plus the fact that you've paid your $$ up front for Prime services, would probably make a buyer use Amazon Prime services. It's a rather tricky marketing tool, but it works for them. It's sort of the "you pay me now or you pay me later" mentality.

I order from Amazon weekly, if not more often, and am amazed at the swift delivery, the ease of returns, and the amazing breadth of products offered. My only concern has been with the packaging a few times--I ordered some liquid garden products that included organic pest control. That came in a large box that also included a WaterPik & accessories. The bottles of garden products leaked all over the box and other contents, and it leaked all over the postal carrier's vehicle. Amazon replace the items, which was nice, but the stink and aggravation was unwelcome... No edible or health care products ever should be packed with pest control products--no commonsense there! On another occasion, I ordered a three-jar pack of Lingonberries. These were bound together in a manner that would suggest safety, but the middle jar was smashed and leaked sticky goo all over everything else in the box--insufficient packing material had been used--those air pillows had shifted all over, the box was too large, and it seemed, again, that commonsense was absent in the packing process. Amazon always replaces items such as this, but they could save money and time and customer anger if a little more "thought" went into the packing process. If robots pack, however, they need to be programmed accordingly ;)

I am very seasoned consumer on Amazon and have just experienced a few watch outs. Pay very close attention to small details especially when you need a product in a short time frame. Primarily, when the product is not coming from an Amazon fulfillment center. In the last 2 weeks I had 2 orders bite me. One was coming direct from China and the other from India. The China order was simply a pair of mini USB power cords, great price, 2 for $5.49. The deal was so great I missed the details, ordered at 8:00 PM, by 11:00 PM I was notified that the product was already shipped. Blown away, however, it was really shipped the next business day as it was coming from China. And it was sent regular mail. Goty the product 3 weeks later. So my haste cost me as I had ordered for a friend who required the product right away. The order from India, also took 3 weeks, but this was goofy, maybe culture or whatever, they shipped the product registered mail. What a royal pain. I have product shipped to my condo in Florida and my neighbour puts the product away for me awaiting our return. UPS and FedEx are great, they know our place always leave it where required. But registered mail, it became a nightmare. Hope my short comings help you in the future.

I'm a tough one to please when it comes to online buying & selling, but Amazon deserves 5 stars.  As a buyer: You're dealing with multiple sellers. Amazon is more like the watchdog. They hold the sellerz to high standards & it works out well. I've never had a problem with any orders. The prices are decent & the quality has always been as I expected. I buy often, especially at Christmas so it was worth it for me to buy the Prime membership. The bonus is that you get a LOT of free movies you can watch on TV (like Netflix), plus movies you can buy right from the TV. I've gotten several popular ones for $10-15. As a seller: You have to keep in mind that they do take a commission & price accordingly. A little tip- don't price anything below $8. As long as you're honest in your description, taking pictures if needed, you'll be fine. They make it easy to have your item listed in 5 minutes. They even suggest a price range based on others that are listed. When we decided to down scale & got rid of a lot of stuff I was making $90 a day. A lot more than I would have gotten at a yard sale. I'm helping my brother in law get rid of his books. He has over 200, way more than I can store. With Amazon all I do is list them, & with one little checkmark I notify Amazon that I want them to take over. They have me print out a label & I box & ship them for them to handle. They store them, ship them, collect the money, handle any customer questions & notify me of what I've sold & my profit. The money is deposited right to my bank account. You can do this with anything you sell.

Amazon.com is most likely the best online marketplace you'll ever encounter! Jeff Bezos, the creator of Amazon.com had many complaints on where to find specific items, especially the rare ones, but didn't have time to look at all the stores and online shopping sites for them. He spent many years trying to figure out why, and then it suddenly hit him. He realized there was no such place to buy everything the world has to offer. He then spent many years in website development until he came across a rather unusual phenomenon. The place he was dreaming of was right before his eyes, and with that in mind, he decided to become the founder of such a project. He spent many days trying to come up with a good international name for the company, and then finally decided to name it after one of the most restricted places in all of South America - Amazon (based off the Amazon River). The website's focus has, and always has been the practice and motto of the customer always being right, making it the best place to find exactly what you need, even if they don't necessarily sell what you're looking for 100% in the United States. In fact, many useful products that are imports are being sold to authorized United States retailers today, some of which the seller has opted to allow Amazon to fulfill the delivery of the products. Although the site has a good reputation, there are sometimes criminals that create fake merchant IDs to either steal your money, or otherwise provide you with counterfeit products in your order. For this kind of case, Amazon.com had created the A-to-Z Safe Buying Guarantee, to help protect buyers from potential fraudulent sellers. Even criminals who close their Amazon.com accounts before the order is complete can still be subject to the system, as the seller ID remains on Amazon.com servers until the 60-day A-to-Z claim filing period has passed, making this the safest place to buy with confidence. If you're ever looking for a hard to find item, who knows! It just may be on Amazon! I'd highly recommend it!
